After contacting Governor Scott Walker’s office on Saturday, I applaud his quick action in joining with fellow governors in calling on President Obama to not resettle additional Syrian refugees in Wisconsin. To read my entire statement, go to SenatorKapenga.com. #wipolitics #wiright
Journal Times editorial: Pause Syrian refugee program until security is in place

Unfortunately, until the US is in a position to be able to properly vet all Syrian refugees entering the country, we cannot accept the influx due to obvious, glaring security issues.



Today Wisconsin representatives signed a letter to the federal government refusing to accept Syrian refugees in Wisconsin.



Read the letter here and view the signers:
Here is the letter I signed requesting that no Syrian refugees be sent to Wisconsin at this time.

"In light of these horrific and tragic attacks, our first priority must be to protect our citizens.  Along with governors across the country, I have deep concerns about the Obama Administration’s plan to accept 10,000 or more Syrian refugees, especially given that one of the Paris attackers was reportedly a Syrian refugee.  In consultation with our Adjutant General, who also serves as my Homeland Security Advisor, it is clear that the influx of Syrian refugees poses a threat.



With this in mind, I am calling upon the President to immediately suspend the program pending a full review of its security and acceptance procedures.  The State of Wisconsin will not accept new Syrian refugees."

Statement from Rep. Kerkman on Governor’s Disapproval of Kenosha Casino



“The announcement that Governor Walker has rejected the Kenosha casino comes as a true disappointment.  I am saddened at the loss of potential for Kenosha County and for the State of Wisconsin.  Great strides were made along the path to this determination and I greatly respect the diligence shown by Governor Walker to try to bring us to a more positive decision.  Ultimately, the compact negotiated by Governor Doyle with the Forest County Potawatomi provided more obstacles than could be reasonably overcome in the decision timeframe.  

We need to keep our focus forward. We will continue to explore other opportunities to bring additional jobs to Kenosha and grow opportunity in southeastern Wisconsin through a pro-job and strong business focus.   While this particular option will not move forward, I believe that recent Kenosha boom will spark even more development and look forward to entertaining additional options for growing the Kenosha economy.”

@SJohnsonWPR: Here's the Fiscal Bureau's analysis of the GOP plan to finance a new arena for the Milwaukee Bucks:

Today the Milwaukee Bucks arena plan advanced out of the Assembly to Governor Walker. I have been a strong advocate for programs and initiatives that work to create jobs and promote economic prosperity for communities and families in Wisconsin.



Advancing this proposal, however, comes only weeks after we passed a budget that included things like detrimental cuts to public education at every level, dismantling of conservationist and aging and long-term care programs, and attacks on working families and wages.



We must prioritize and provide consistent support to things like public schools before we can begin to consider prioritizing for extraneous projects. Until we can fully fund fundamental public benefits that already exist in our state, I cannot support taxpayer-subsidized sports arenas while things like public education, health care, and working families are on the chopping block.

Senator Risser Statement on Governor’s Budget Bill



Governor Walker’s budget proposal is clearly aimed at a national audience at the expense of the citizens of our state.  



The Governor proposes to borrowing $1.3 billion to build new highways for two years while our public schools crumble.  



Public education is the state’s biggest and most important investment yet Governor Walker proposes gutting the University of Wisconsin by $300 million.  This is in stark contrast with the Republican governors of other Midwestern states, notably Ohio, Indiana and Iowa, which are increasing their funding for higher education.  



Also, Wisconsin is now the only Great Lakes state to refuse federal funds to strengthen our Medicaid program.  Accepting federal healthcare dollars could help prevent funding cuts to local schools, public health, police and fire services, local infrastructure repair, and many other important programs and services.

Attended the Governor's Council on Workforce Investment today in Madison and heard a deeply depressing presentation by the state's economist about the current and future state of WI's workforce as the population ages and the number of people of working age flat lines.  I took the opportunity to point out that we had great ideas in CWI's 10 year workforce plan related to public K-12 schools, universities and tech colleges to help build our workforce but that if Governor Walker's proposed budget goes through these schools/universities/tech colleges won't have money to implement them or they will have to cut other key programs.
Thanks to the bipartisan committee members for their work on the important issue of attracting more workers to careers in the trades.

Applied Data Consultants, Inc. hosted a meeting on Fast Forward, the bill I authored to help address the skills gap. Jobs, trades and internship session with NWTC administration this morning .  Continuing to do more to integrate WIsconsin education for career and community readiness!! Creating more tax payers and less taxes!! #thinkWisconsinFirst #WiFi

A couple days ago I got to tour the Cardinal Glass plant in Menomonie with plant manager Wayne McAtee. It was a great tour and I learned a lot about how glass is made. The hottest part of their oven is 1600 degrees Celsius!!



But perhaps the most important thing I learned, as a possible Representative, came from good talks in Wayne's office. What I learned is that employers like Cardinal are having a hard time getting good workers to fill their job openings.  As a Representative I would work on this issue. We always try to increase the number of jobs available to people in our area, but I think we need to spend some time making sure we have the good workers that employers are looking for to fill those jobs too.



Thanks for your time and open conversations with me about finding quality employees Wayne!

@andrewlacombe: UPDATE: Budget committee approves spending more on drug treatment

Instead of adding new roadblocks for families and seniors already struggling to put food on their tables, these bills put the focus right back where it needs to be – on better nutrition outcomes for FoodShare participants.

The Wisconsin State Assembly is in session. Today we're taking up legislation to require people on food stamps to shop from a list of "healthy" foods meant for pregnant women and infants, as well as force people to pee in a cup in order to get their food and unemployment benefits. This legislation is meant as a distraction from the Republicans' harmful budget that guts our public programs, from education to natural resources to long-term care programs and state parks. 



If Assembly Republicans are serious about forcing these policies on people who live in poverty, they should lead by example and pee in a cup every time they accept their paychecks, per diems, and mileage reimbursements, and they should be willing to eat food from the same list they're forcing on others. It's that simple. Assembly Democrats introduced "us first" amendments to hold them to this, but of course they rejected them. It's easy to tell others what to do when you're not willing to do it too.

"Barnes says the work requirement rule that impacted the FoodShare program in April hasn't been successful. He says only 7% in Milwaukee have found employment to keep their benefits, and 2,700 per month are being kicked out of the program.

Can Wisconsin replicate Maine’s food stamp success?

Madison- State Representative Janel Brandtjen (R- Menomonee Falls) has introduced legislation designed to restore the original intent of Wisconsin’s foodshare program. AB 177 coauthored by Rep. Rob Brooks (R-Saukville) and Brandtjen will provide oversight as to what food items may be purchased by those using taxpayer dollars to help feed their families.  



Right now a family of four can get up to $649 per month to provide food for their families.  Under current law, the head of the household can spend the entire amount on non-nutritional items that could lead to obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure and other health related issues.  



“We in the legislature have an obligation to make sure hard earned tax dollars are spent appropriately.  While I’m confident that most families do not abuse the program this bill assures that 67% of the food share dollars provided to families are spent on healthy foods including meats, vegetables and dairy products.” Brandtjen said. “The bill is about protecting the integrity of a program that uses taxpayer dollars.” She added.



In addition to the requirement that 67% of foodshare dollars a family spends is spent on nutritious food, the bill also prohibits the purchase of high end items such as lobster, crab or shrimp. Representative Brandtjen points out that the families who currently make nutritious purchases will not notice a change in the program.

Today we celebrate Labor Day. 



Labor Day is a time to reflect on the significant contributions Wisconsin’s workers have made to our state. It’s also a time for us to consider how we can improve Wisconsin’s workplace conditions.  



Since the early 20th century, Wisconsin’s workforce has sought fair treatment and workplace conditions for all. In fact, Wisconsin was an early supporter of the labor movement, passing the first workman’s compensation law in 1911. 



Despite initial progress in workers’ rights, harmful anti-worker legislation which severely limited public and private unions, and the repeal of the Equal Pay Enforcement Act, which resulted in equal pay for men and women – have made their way into Wisconsin law.



Today, with a minimum wage set at $7.25, low-wage workers are struggling to make ends meet. Also, women in Wisconsin are paid an average of 78 cents for every dollar men are paid. 



These wage inequalities put our Wisconsin workforce in a competitive disadvantage nationally, hurting not only individual workers and their families, but also our state’s economy as a whole.  



Wisconsin Democrats have stressed the importance of workers’ rights, and we continue to fight for fair wages for low-income workers, for women’s rights to equal pay, and for the right of all Wisconsinites to a safe work environment. 



Our workers are the backbone of our economy, and it is only with their success that Wisconsin can achieve true prosperity. 



Thank you, and have a good Labor Day.

As we enjoy this three-day weekend filled with camping, family cook-outs and saying goodbye to summer, please take time to remember who made the holiday possible and why we celebrate it.



In 1894 the Labor Movement convinced the federal government to dedicate the first Monday each September to American workers and their fight for rights in the workplace.  They also dedicated it to the celebration of the social and economic achievements and well-being brought to us by American workers.



But Labor Day, and really the whole weekend, is a time for Americans also to thank the teachers, sanitation workers, construction trades workers, home health workers, snowplow drivers, nurses and all the workers who make it possible for us and our loved ones to live free of the diseases, ignorance, dangers and inconveniences that people over a century ago lived with constantly.  



Here in Wisconsin some might think we have little to celebrate since Governor Walker began his attack on working families in 2011.  I disagree. I believe that the Labor Movement is coming back bigger and stronger than ever!



Take the time this Labor Day to show your support for workers and their families by joining in your community’s celebrations.  March with your unions, attend their parades and cheer on our workers!  



I will be joining my friends from IBEW on Monday, Sept. 7th in the Milwaukee Labor Day parade to Laborfest at the Summerfest grounds (details below).  Hope to see you there! 



Laborfest 2015 ( Mon, Sept. 7th) begins with the 11:00 am parade at the Wisconsin Workers Memorial in Zeidler Square downtown, and continues at the Summerfest grounds until 5:00 pm. 



As always, Laborfest is free and open to the public, with plenty to eat and drink, live music, games and fun for kids, professional wrestling (!), a classic car show, and a raffle to win a Harley Davidson bike. 

 

Laborfest is organized and sponsored by local unions and businesses like I.B. Electrical Workers Local 494; United Steel Workers Local 2-292; the Harley-Davidson Motor Company; the MillerCoors Company and its trade unions; and the Milwaukee Area Labor Council.

In November 2012, Governor Walker appointed Reed Hall, an attorney and director of Marshfield Clinic, as the interim CEO of the Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation (WEDC), the governor's flagship jobs agency.



The appointment puzzled many due to Reed Hall's lack of experience in economic development. 



After a $40,000 national search for a new CEO paid for by Wisconsin taxpayers, the governor decided instead to remove the 'interim' from Reed Hall's title and name him CEO of WEDC. Mr. Hall had contributed to Gov. Walker's campaign in the past.



A few weeks ago, while discussing WEDC's continued failures, I stood on the Assembly floor and said about WEDC, "If you're not outraged, then you're not paying attention." Under Governor Walker's leadership, WEDC has been an unmitigated disaster.



Since those remarks, WEDC has continued to show its lack of competence. Most recently, we learned that more than two dozen awards worth more than $124 million were made to companies without a formal staff review by WEDC's underwriting department.



Today, citing fraud, waste, and abuse, Rep. Peter Barca and Sen. Julie Lassa, the Democratic representatives of the WEDC board, called for Reed Hall to resign. I join their call and ask Governor Walker to take action to fix the problem he created.

My republican colleagues talk about scandal, mismanagement, corruption, waste, and abuse a lot of the floor. They're usually saying it in the context of demeaning and attacking a growing number of folks who are already down and going through tough times. 



Never, not once, have I heard my republican colleagues address the WEDC scandal. Waste, fraud, and abuse has run rampant and they have remained silent on it. Why? 



Is it because they'd have to confront the millions of dollars and obvious cronyism that involved their big campaign spenders? Is it because we're talking about huge amounts of money going to rich folks instead of help being given to those in need? 



Is it because they find it easier to pick on working class neighbors than to confront their white collar cronies?



Any way you slice it this is the Wisconsin they've crafted. Corruption, cronyism, jobs leaving left and right, and an education system that's spiraling out of control in order to appease privatizing corporate masters like Scott Jensen.



This is exactly what the Republicans ruling out state want, and this is what happens when they are in charge.

Wisconsin Senate Democrats 

2015 Badger Blueprint agenda



Today the Senate Democrats announced the WI Badger Blueprint. We have been and remain committed to listening to people throughout the state and this agenda reflects that. It includes a wide range of positive new ideas and proven solutions to create economic opportunities for all and restore fairness in our state. 



I want to share and echo the comments of our Senate Democratic Leader Jennifer Shilling: “The Badger Blueprint is a reflection of our shared Wisconsin values and it provides a clear vision to help strengthen our state.  By focusing on policies that encourage growth, drive innovation and increase economic opportunities, we can move Wisconsin forward in a positive direction.”



Wisconsin Senate Democrats 

2015 Badger Blueprint agenda



Wisconsin’s hardworking families want leaders to work together and focus on improving the economy, strengthening the middle class and boosting family wages. 



The Badger Blueprint agenda that Senate Democrats are putting forward includes a wide range of new ideas and proven solutions to create economic opportunities and help move Wisconsin forward.



Many of these proposals should have bipartisan support and we are hopeful that the majority party will work with us to focus on these issues and address the challenges that our state is facing. 



Senate Dem Badger Blueprint agenda:



• Growth

o Senate Democrats understand that the best way to move Wisconsin forward is by growing the middle class and expanding economic security. 

o From early childhood to technical training and college – ensuring educational opportunities for all Wisconsin residents will boost our long-term ability to compete and succeed in the modern day, global market.



• Innovation

o For Wisconsin to be competitive in today’s global economy, we need a modern and well-maintained infrastructure. 

o From our roads and bridges, to our water treatment and sewer systems, to our broadband and rail networks – it’s time to reinvest in Wisconsin’s infrastructure to encourage business growth, foster workforce opportunities and attract private investments.



• Opportunity

o Too many Wisconsinites are being held back by a system that has been designed by special interests to give the wealthy and big businesses a greater advantage over hardworking families. 

o Through targeted middle class tax relief and improved workplace flexibilities for Wisconsin families, we can restore fairness in our state, increase economic opportunities and strengthen our communities.

Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, described our Union as "perpetual," "unbroken," and that it would "endure forever." The Assembly debated the so-called "Right to Work" bill (SB 44). Here is a part of my speech on the floor in opposition to this bill:



"At its best, America too is about helping workers earn family-earning wages. America is about helping people get access to good health care, and secure their pensions for their retirement. America is about helping young people pursue training at schools and tech colleges, and work in safe workplaces. Americans pay our dues—our federal, state, and local income taxes—and we don’t ever like to pay them and we don’t always agree with what our government does. But is it fair to get the benefits of the American union without paying our dues? Would anyone in this room feel more free by opting out of America? I know I wouldn’t."

Senate Bill 44, the Right-to-Work legislation, was passed by the Assembly this morning 62-35 after a 24-hour session. Thanks to each person - both for and against the bill - that took the time to contact me and share their opinions. Here is my statement:



For Immediate Release             March 6, 2015



Statement by Rep. Mary Czaja on Vote for Worker Freedom



Madison… Today, after a marathon 24-hour session, the Wisconsin State Assembly has voted to pass Senate Bill 44, commonly referred to as the Right-to-Work legislation. After passage, Rep. Mary Czaja (R-Irma) issued the following statement:



“I cast my vote in favor of the Right-to-Work legislation for two reasons. First, this is an issue of worker freedom. Right-to-Work protects the right for Wisconsin workers to freely associate and preserves their ability to pay membership dues voluntarily rather than by force. I firmly believe it is the right of the worker to make that choice, and I will always stand up for personal freedoms.



“My second reason for supporting the bill is to help Wisconsin remain competitive with both our neighboring Midwestern states and the global economy. Just this week we heard testimony in the Joint Finance Committee that 70% of employers consider the Right-to-Work status of a state when deciding where to invest and grow jobs. The state of Wisconsin and our northern economy cannot afford to be left out of that equation. I have appreciated the many calls and contacts from constituents over the last couple weeks, and I am committed to working together in growing our state’s business climate.”



Senate Bill 44 now moves to the Governor’s desk for his approval; he is expected to sign the bill next week Monday.

We have programs in place that will subsidize childcare in a child development center or similar setting already. But, they have to charge more for their services due to overhead, paying staff, lease, insurance etc. they do not provide overnight care. A real gap in services for third shifters. And they often do not provide care for infants. If you allow, for example a grandparent or other family member of a child to care for the child/ten and be paid (much less than you would a center) it would in many cases supplement their fixed income such as SS. Give the child's parents a greater piece of mind because the child is with someone they know and trust. And it will allow them to succeed at work or school. Lastly, it would save taxpayers money because you do not have to pay them as much. I know this works, when I was going to college I took advantage of a program like this in Texas. My sister who had Lupus and was disabled cared for my 3 kids. We all benefitted, she supplemented her income, I completed my education and my kids got to spend time with their aunt and cousins.

If we're spending more money than ever before, why is the current administration telling us they don't have enough to fund our schools? If we're spending more money than ever before, where is it going?



The answer lies with corporations legally-bribing politicians with campaign contributions. These politicians then spend our tax dollars to increase the company's profits.



One big example is Travis Tranel's vote for the "Manufacturing and Agriculture Credit." It gives away $284 million annually, 78% of which goes to people earning more than $1 million a year. Why is he taking tax dollars from working families and giving them to the wealthiest people in the state? ...And if this was supposed to create jobs and “trickle down” to the middle class, why is Wisconsin's economy lagging behind the nation and our region?



Another example is replacing publicly-run state services with FOR-PROFIT companies (voucher schools; $100 million increase in private contractors administering medicaid since 2011; Medicaid spending increased by $3 billion while the number of people served barely increased). The answer is legal-bribery. That's why this referendum issue keeps popping up. It's not that there isn't money in the budget, its that these bought-and-paid-for politicians are funneling it to their profit-crazy campaign contributors.

Next week I will be traveling to the country of Chile. Where I will bring my wife's ashes to her resting place over looking the Pacific Ocean. 



I am looking forward to visiting with my Chilean family and friends. 



Every time I think of Chile, our Wisconsin public school system comes to my mind.  My beautiful Chilean grand daughter, Sarah, started pre-k in LaCrosse while her father studies as a foreign graduate student at UWL.



My step son is amazed at the quality of education Sarah is receiving.  In Chile public education is improving, but most middle class and upper class families send their children to private schools. 



I worked at one of the best knowned and most expensive private schools in Chile. In my opinion, the Nekoosa Public Schools, where I worked for 18 years, provides a overall better education than that expensive Chilean private school.



Why have we repeatedly heard the matra: our public schools are failing? We need to ask ourselves where did this matra come from, and why is it being repeated. 



There are numerous organizations that seek to privatize Wisconsin Public Education. ALEC, the American Legislation Exchange Council, who receives funding from the Koch brothers and other billionaires have the privatization of Wisconsin Public Schools near the top of their agenda. The American Federation for Children is another organization that is trying to privatize our public schools.



Corporate America has very good reasons for convincing us our Traditional Public Schools are failing. They want to cash in on our kids, and they are getting help to that end from our elected officials who put corporate interests before the interests of our communities.



Here in the 72nd district our public schools have in recent years lost valuable educational programs and have experienced rising class sizes. Meanwhile, districts have to pay the tuition of students already attending private schools. 



Around the state communities are faced with raising property taxes to pay for the added expense of private school vouchers.



Again, who asked for this? Was it the members of our communities, or was it corporations who want to cash in on our kids. 



Scott Krug's campaign has taken donations from the American Federation for Children, and he also accepted an ALEC "Scholarship." In fact his largest contributor in 2012 was the American Federation for Children. They gave his campaign a whooping  $12,000. This may have been a reward for sponsoring a Special Education Voucher bill in 2011.



Our elected officials need to do the will of the people not the will of their big donors.



Community rights before corporate intetests, amen!



As they say in Chile :chao pescado! Translation: later fish!

HESSELBEIN: STUDENTS AND FOR-PROFIT COLLEGES WIN

IN JOINT FINANCE ACTION TO KEEP EDUCATIONAL APPROVAL BOARD

Rep. Dianne Hesselbein today praised the vote of the Joint Finance Committee not to eliminate the Educational Approval Board, calling it a victory for both students and schools.

“Keeping the Educational Approval Board alive and on guard is a win for students, who will be protected from exploitation, and a win for schools, which will be protected against unscrupulous competition and given legitimacy,” said Hesselbein, D-Middleton. “It will also save the state more than $100,000 a year in contributions to the general fund.

“On April 16, I issued an appeal to save the agency in which I said: ‘We hope that cool heads will prevail when the Joint Finance Committee takes up the elimination of the Educational Approval Board and that this misbegotten proposal will simply and quietly go away.’ That is what exactly what has happened. Everyone should applaud this victory for good government as we begin our national holiday.”

The Educational Approval Board, established nearly 60 years ago, gives annual fitness checkups and certifications to 174 for-profit institutions and 78 out-of-state nonprofit schools, with a total enrollment of 60,000. They range from large universities like Globe, the University of Phoenix and DeVry to specialized schools like the Sun Prairie Diesel Truck Driving School.

Gov. Scott Walker proposed in his budget to eliminate the independent EAB and scatter some of its functions to other state offices. That proposal failed Thursday night in a 12-4 vote on an omnibus motion that scrapped several of the governor’s agency merger and reorganization plans. Democrats on Joint Finance voted against the motion because they wanted separate consideration of the troubled Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation.

"In the last decade, Wisconsin has cut back sharply on funding its state university system.



In 2003, students paid about 30 percent of the University of Wisconsin system’s total educational cost, according to data compiled by the State Higher Education Executive Officers Association. By 2013, after several rounds of state budget cuts, students were responsible for about 47 percent, and more state cuts to higher education are expected.



By 2014, 70 percent of Wisconsin students graduated with debt—the third-highest percentage in the nation for students at public and nonprofit colleges, according to the nonprofit Institute for College Access & Success, or TICAS.



We ought to invest in the future, not take from the future,” says Thomas G. Mortenson, a senior scholar at the Pell Institute for the Study of Opportunity in Higher Education. “Where I used to live we called that eating our seed corn.”



-- Consumer Reports, June 28, 2016

Yesterday I attended Governor Walker’s visit to Fox Valley Technical College, which highlighted the state’s efforts to make college more affordable. Last spring I voted to provide an additional $1 million over the next two years in the Wisconsin Grant Program specifically for technical college students. These efforts, in addition to the tuition freeze for UW students, will help make college more affordable for Wisconsin families.

Last night I had the pleasure of attending Emerge Wisconsin's annual Woman of the Year dinner in Milwaukee.  I am a proud graduate of the Emerge Wisconsin Class of 2015, so these events are very important to me. 



The organization is dedicated to electing more women to local, state and federal office because, as Executive Director Erin Forrest pointed out, there are still far too few women at all those levels. 



While Wisconsin has elected more than 200 men to Congress since statehood, only two women - Sen. Tammy Baldwin and Rep. Gwen Moore - have held similar offices in this state.  



Things aren't much better on the local level. 74% of Wisconsin's town boards and 24% of the state's village boards currently have NO women members.  The current male-to-female ratio in the Wisconsin Legislature is 75% men to 25% women.



This year's Woman of the Year is Heather Colburn, president of Colburn Consulting in Madison, and a successful, behind-the-scenes adviser for many political candidates and organizations. Colburn used her acceptance speech to encourage those in the room, especially the women, to support aspiring women everywhere.  



"That's why we have two hands," Colburn said. "One hand is to help you climb the ladder of success yourself. The other is to help the women behind you also break glass ceilings."



She also urged attendees to say "Yes" when female candidates ask for financial support. "Making those fundraising calls is one of the hardest thing a woman candidate does," Colburn said. "When she calls you, please give. Give generously."

As a result, we have taken several giant steps backward when it comes to equal access to health care, pay equity, and even the right to vote on Election Day. We have come a long way since the days of the Suffragettes fighting for our right to vote, yet we have much work to do."

Today, the Assembly Committee on Ways and Means held a public hearing on legislation to return excess stadium sales tax to Brown County and its municipalities. Last week the Senate unanimously passed this bill, and I am excited to see it continuing to move forward in the Assembly as well. The bill will likely be voted on by the full Assembly in October.

Yesterday the Green Bay City Council voted to use excess stadium sales tax funds for economic development projects, infrastructure improvements, and lead water pipe replacement. The Council also voted to transfer three of its unused liquor licenses to Ashwaubenon for use in the Titletown District development. I am excited to see legislation I worked on this session come full circle and have a positive impact on our community.

“Today is a good day for Wisconsin. We need to work on keeping energy affordable, safe and environmentally friendly, and bringing nuclear energy back to Wisconsin will do just that,” said Rep. Macco. “With this bill, Wisconsin will be a nationwide leader in nuclear energy.”



Wisconsin’s moratorium was enacted in 1982 because of concerns about storage and safety. With significant technological advances of the past 30 years, large scale storage facilities are no longer needed, and the facilities have become significantly safer.



“This bill is a good example of what happens when you are able to bring a group of stake holders together to solve a problem,” continued Rep. The non-partisan Legislative Fiscal Bureau released an updated review of the state's general fund today.  For people who enjoy numbers, the full report is linked below.  Here are some highlights:



-the state's ending balance at the end of the biennium (July, 2017) is projected to be $94.3 million lower than the previous estimate.

-the state is projected to spend more than it takes in.

-individual income tax revenue is projected to be almost $237 million lower (due largely to lower wage and salary growth).

-we will transfer $77.5 million from the general fund to the transportation fund.

-$25.4 million less will be claimed in the homestead and earned income tax credits (these help low-income working families and seniors).

-state agencies are expected to return over $1 billion from their allocated budgets to the general fund.

-we will have enough money in reserve to run the state for about 9 1/2 days.

After more than a month of closed-door debates, we are finally seeing some movement on the state budget. FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:

February 3, 2015



CONTACT: Rep. Considine

(608) 266-7746



Rep. Dave Considine Comments on Gov. Walker’s Budget Address



MADISON – Tonight, Governor Scott Walker delivered his 2015-2017 biennial budget address in the Assembly Chambers. Representative Dave Considine issued the following statement regarding the Governor’s budget.



“My focus, and the focus of my Assembly Democratic colleagues, is on restoring economic opportunities for Wisconsin families. I sincerely hope Governor Walker will join us in this goal, but I am very concerned about the priorities he has outlined in his budget for the next biennium,” said Rep. Considine.



In his address, Gov. Walker referenced plans to give the state’s outstanding University of Wisconsin system more autonomy in funding. However, he failed to mention that this would mean cuts of hundreds of millions of dollars, in addition to tuition freezes for both the UW System and our technical colleges. He also announced his intention to rely on $1.3 billion in borrowed money to fund transportation projects, further indebting future generations. Finally, the Governor announced plans to lift the cap on vouchers, taking more money away from our precious public school systems which have made our state great.



“These ideas will not create jobs or the economic, educational, or recreational opportunities Wisconsinites so badly need, and they are not the solutions to our state’s problems,” Rep. Considine stated. “Instead of taking aim at public education and continuing to borrow funds on top of a $280 million budget deficit, we should be working together to create sustainable jobs and ensure that every child in Wisconsin has access to a high-quality education.”

Last night, following months of hearings and debate, the State Assembly passed the 2015-17 biennial state budget bill.  I voted in favor of the bill, which, if signed by Governor Scott Walker, would result in a balanced budget with no tax increases.  Additionally, the budget includes the lowest amount of bonding in nearly 30 years, middle class tax relief, and a repeal of prevailing wage laws for local governments. If my colleagues across the aisle really believe in the First Amendment, they should put their money where their mouth is and sign onto my bill protecting public employees first amendment rights and their right to be free of retaliation by the Governor and Legislature!  



Here's a sneak peak of the co-sponsorship memo I sent around yesterday:



“Free speech rights need to be protected.  I will always fight for free speech… I fundamentally believe in free speech.  Free speech should not be allowed in some cases and restricted in others.  As Republicans, we should be advocating for individual liberties and not limiting them.” - Rep. Scott Allen (R-Waukesha) October 20 & 21



“There is nothing more un-American than being investigated, interrogated and intimidated because you have exercised your First Amendment Rights by engaging in the political process.” – Rep. Janel Brandtjen (R-Menomonee Falls) October 22



“Protecting constitutional rights is something every legislator has sworn an oath to do.  The First Amendment right to speech is first for a reason.” Sen. Tom Tiffany (R-Hazelhurst) and Sen. Van Wanggaard (R-Racine) October 9



Indeed, as our colleagues recognize above, First Amendment rights should be respected for all, whether you are singing in the Capitol rotunda, holding a sign in the Assembly Gallery or as a public employee, expressing an opinion.  



Yet too often, we hear of public employees who are targeted for simply doing their jobs.  Threats of losing staff, having an office budget eliminated, being transferred to another unit or eliminated.  A few recent examples…



Talk about Global Warming?  Gag order.  

Print the findings of your scientific research?  Staff positions eliminated.

Follow the law and faithfully execute the duties of your position?  Bureau transferred and direct oversight given to political appointee. 

Write a letter to the editor?  Not so fast – you received an internal memo saying you couldn’t discuss your job publicly.

Political journalism scan - A friend, (Don), in Rome points out the Attorney General pushed out long term Environmental Law Unit Director Tom Dawson, who was responsible for protecting public rights in water and other natural resources.  



C'mon, what is the matter with people?



Lackeys in the legislature, DNR and the Department of Justice are selling out our state. I've been a Wisconsin citizen all of my life and I have never seen anything like this, not close.



"Think about the water issue when you cast your ballot in November," writes Don.



Yes, we will.

"It is my hope that Republicans will stop obstructing action on clean water and instead work with Democratic legislators on the state’s groundwater crisis. We must require the DNR to follow their own water quality rules and provide them with the staff they need to ensure that our water is safe and drinkable. We must have accountability when it comes to enforcing the state’s groundwater rules. People should continue to apply pressure on their elected officials to find sustainable solutions to our water quality crisis — before it’s too late."



— Rep. Katrina Shankland

This is by no means an exhaustive study of what I have worked on during the past year or am actively researching for my next term, however, I am pretty thorough and open.  I will be posting my work, broken into a series of ten topics, over the next couple of weeks.



I have actually been accused of being too honest.  I feel that honesty is a virtue and I will continue to run my office with integrity.  As such, I feel that even though some of these issues have not been fully vetted, I want all of you, my constituents, to know exactly what I have been accomplishing and advocating for on your behalf - irregardless of what the daily news media feel are the hot, sexy topics.



No one will be able to accuse me of misrepresenting myself when I ran for my first elected office in 2014.



Keep in mind, my office, like every other freshman Assembly office, runs with one Legislative Aide (LA) and me.



(Oh yes, and for those who don't believe me, I have notes as to where many of these bills originated... it should be noted that quite a few are from constituent ideas.)

I joined my colleagues in welcoming Canadian Consul General Roy Norton to the state Capitol yesterday. Consul General Norton is visiting the state this week as part of Canada Week in Wisconsin.



I was happy to be part of Canada Day at the state Capitol, and to welcome Consul General Norton to Wisconsin. Our Wisconsin/Canadian relations are a very important part of our economy. Wisconsin sells more goods to Canada than the next six largest foreign markets combined.



While in Madison, Consul General Norton was on hand as the state Assembly passed Assembly Joint Resolution 76, proclaiming October 26 to 30, 2015, as Canada Week in Wisconsin, and Tuesday, October 27, 2015, as Canada Day at the state Capitol.



The Consul General had the following to say about his visit:



“Our welcome in the state Capitol today could not have been warmer. This underscores the tremendous relationship between Canada and Wisconsin. We are one another's best customers with more than $12.4 billion in annual trade between us. I look forward to visiting again and to further grow this mutually beneficial relationship."



In addition to the strong trade relations, the US hosts more tourists from Canada than any other country. Wisconsin welcomes 320,700 Canadian visitors every year, putting $65 million into our tourism industry.



The Consul General will be traveling around Wisconsin this week, ending his trip in Madison on Saturday.

"Democrats, who have no tools available to slow down the legislation, are left arguing that the state does not want it. Barnes, who hope(d) to amend the changes to delay their implementation past 2016, pointed to the 59 Wisconsin towns that have already passed non-binding referenda against the Supreme Court's landmark Citizens United decision.



"'I’ve talked to Republicans who have heartburn about the bill,' Barnes said. 'But are they gonna vote against it? I don’t think so. The 2016 cycle is going to be a presidential election, and Democrats have traditional outperformed in cycles like that. Governor Walker's approval rating has fallen below 40 percent, and Republicans are going to be tied to him. Is that why we're seeing these bills now? To me, that seems like a conflict of interest.'"

Representative Bob Gannon (of the "shoot the thugs" and "black people in Milwaukee are holding the state back" press releases) is now advocating for a Constitutional Convention to rein in out-of-control federal government spending.  (Never mind that the federal deficit has decreased over 67% during President Obama's term.)  The group held a lobby day at the Capitol today.



An elderly gentleman visited my office this afternoon to drop off petitions supposedly from my constituents in support of this effort.  One of the names seemed very familiar.  I received an e-mail from this woman a year ago on the same issue.  I sent her a hard-copy letter at that time explaining my position.



Imagine my surprise when the woman’s daughter contacted me to say her mother had been deceased for over a year!  I contacted the Convention of the States people, but never heard back.



I am appalled and disgusted that this group would still be using the name of this woman who has been dead for TWO YEARS now to try to advance its cause.  How can I, or any of my legislative colleagues, trust the veracity of any communications we get from these people?

"Without demonstrable public will and with strong opposition from environmentalists, hunters, anglers, the Department of the Interior, and the outdoor recreation industry, among others, Republican lawmakers are attempting to transfer control of your public lands from federal to state governments in a thinly-veiled attempt to force their sale for purposes of resource exploitation. Now, the first blow has been struck. 



Last week, the House committee on Natural Resources voted to adopt HR 3650, the summary of which reads:



“This bill directs the Department of Agriculture, through the Forest Service, to convey to a state up to 2 million acres of eligible portions of the National Forest System (NFS) in it that it elects to acquire through enactment by the state legislature of a bill meeting certain criteria. Portions of the NFS conveyed to a state shall be administered and managed primarily for timber production.”

At the end of each legislative session, the Wisconsin League of Conservation Voters publishes the Conservation Scorecard so you can see how your legislator and others are voting on the issues you care about. I am glad to be among some of my other colleagues as a Conservation Champion with a perfect 100%. It’s clear this was one of the worst legislative sessions for conservation. But we were able make some progress with the Stewardship Program, stopping the water privatization bill, and protecting our waterways from plastic micro-beads. Check it out!

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services is proposing to remove the HCAHPS survey pain management questions from the hospital payment scoring calculation, the agency said Wednesday.



Many clinicians report feeling pressure to overprescribe opioids because scores on the HCAHPS survey pain management questions are tied to Medicare payments to hospitals, CMS said.

Today, Governor Walker signed a bill I authored, AB 810 into law at Lock 3 in Appleton. This law allows DOA to transfer a parcel of land to the City of Appleton to be used by the Fox River Navigational Authority to build a visitor center. The visitor center will provide valuable tourism and educational opportunities by showcasing the history and significance of the Fox River. Special thanks to Representative Jim Steinke and Dr. Timothy Rose for their help in crafting this legislation.

"Because, quite frankly, persons of color don't need another white person to chime in on issues of systemic racism in our community, our state, or our country. Or to tell persons of color what their best interests are. Or to tell them how they should go about dismantling the system that oppresses them. Indeed, if the last three weeks of public discourse have taught white progressives anything, it's that one year after Ferguson, we still fail to listen more than we talk.



So while I could have devoted the 600 words I’m allowed here to talk about systemic, structural and institutional racism, I’m going to stop here as a symbolic reminder and plea to myself and my fellow white progressives: There’s a difference between complacent silence and actively listening, and we can and must listen better."

THE NEWS IS IN!!!



I would like to take this opportunity to thank my family and friends for supporting me through the last several months of campaigning, and all of my volunteers for their tremendous efforts to help make this primary victory possible. Thank you to all of you for the support and trust you have placed in me.  



I’m also deeply grateful for the confidence the voters have placed in me with their votes today.  I am looking forward to a spirited general election campaign and I will continue to run a positive campaign based on issues.  



 I also want to thank Vince Trudell and his family for stepping forward to run in our district. I am very happy I had the opportunity to get to know Vince and respect his genuine concern for this district's issues, his devotion to all of our families, and our communities. Thank you Vince.



As I look forward I am excited to talk about the issues that are important to our area. I would like to use my experience as a small businessman and a farmer to grow our local economy so that we have more good paying jobs for our families, expand economic growth, reduce government over-regulation, provide the best educational opportunities for our children and grandchildren, and reduce taxes.



To learn more about my campaign, please visit www.rob4assembly.net.

Please join me at the home of retired State Senator Judy Robson on Saturday, October 10 for a fundraiser to support my reelection to the State Assembly!



My first ten months as your state representative have given me the opportunity to fight a harmful budget and other policies that would move our state in the wrong direction, while working to restore local control, support our public schools, expand economic opportunity, and ensure fair elections through non-partisan redistricting.



Thank you for your support in giving me this chance to represent you.



Now, I need your help to make sure I have the resources to continue to fight for you the rest of this session and beyond. Your early support will put me in the strongest possible position heading into next year.



Again, please join retired Senator Judy Robson and me for a:



Fundraiser for Mark Spreitzer for Assembly

at the home of retired Senator Judy Robson

2411 E. Ridge Rd., Beloit

Saturday, October 10

2:00-4:00 p.m.



If the weather permits, we'll be outside on Judy's deck overlooking Turtle Creek.



Checks can be addressed to Friends of Mark Spreitzer and mailed to 1718 Henderson Ave., Beloit, WI 53511, or delivered at the fundraiser on October 10.



Sponsorships are still available for $500, $250, or $100, and the suggested contribution is $25. Support in any amount is greatly appreciated.



If you're not able to join us in person, please mail your gift or you can donate online at www.markforassembly.com



Again, thank you for your past support and I hope to see you on October 10!



Sincerely,



Mark

FOR RELEASE: November 2, 2016

CONTACT: Rep. Dianne Hesselbein, 608-266-5340

 

 

 

HESSELBEIN: CAMP RANDALL RACISM SHOWS UGLY CLIMATE OF HATE

 

                The noose around the neck of an African-American figure wearing prison garb and an Obama mask at Camp Randall Stadium Saturday sent a shockwave of hate and fear to students who saw it, and it deserved a more forceful response, Rep. Dianne Hesselbein (D-Middleton) said today.

 

                “This appalling stunt, though accompanied by political trappings and appearing on the same day as Freakfest, was no joke. It crossed the legal line that requires UW-Madison to maintain a safe and non-intimidating campus environment for every student. All students know this country’s traumatic history of lynching. It sent a violent warning.”

 

                The costumed offenders, one dressed as Obama and the other dressed as Donald Trump, were not in the student section and their tickets were re-sold, a spokeswoman for the Dean of Students said today. It is unclear whether they could be subjected to university discipline. But, “in the future, the university needs to respond more forcefully to hooligans,” Hesselbein said. “They should have been expelled immediately.”

 

#     #     #

As we head into the end of the year, now is a great time to reflect on 2015 and start thinking ahead. In the last year, citizens across the 81st District (and Wisconsin) have asked for better support for our children's education, more local control, and a truly accountable government - among other things. Instead, my colleagues in the majority have ignored these requests.



In 2016, I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to put your priorities first, but I need your help. I have greatly appreciated all of your input and support so far, and I want to continue representing your voice in the Legislature in 2016 and beyond. If you are able, please consider giving $25, $50, or whatever you can afford to help support my campaign for re-election.

“I thought bad things happen in threes. First, Republicans passed a bill that opens the door to corruption by exempting political crimes from certain investigations. Number two, we passed a bill that dismantled our ethics and elections watchdog, and the third made campaign finance changes that open the door to unlimited and secret spending by corporations and billionaires. 



Republicans are opening the door to corruption further with this fourth bill. I guess that when you talk about bad things happening in threes, that is only when it's happenstance - not when it’s by design. When it is by design, Republicans put forth four, not three, bills that open the door to corruption and ensure that our state is indeed open to corruption.”

"New Hampshire's unemployment rate is nearly a full point lower than Wisconsin's, and the disparity on income measures is just as stark.  New Hampshire's median household income in 2013 was the highest in the nation, and more than $15,000 higher than Wisconsin's. Not to mention that New Hampshire's business tax climate was ranked 7th best in the nation by the Tax Foundation, while Wisconsin ranked 43rd. Scott Walker should have checked the facts before trying to compare his failed economic record that's hurting middle class families across his state with Governor Hassan's record of encouraging innovation, expanding middle class opportunity, supporting small businesses, and moving New Hampshire's economy forward."

Our movement to preserve our communities is broad-based. Among our allies are scholars and academics. One such ally has passed, Byron H. Shaw, a pioneer in the area of nitrates and groundwater quality.



Said George Kraft, “Byron had a multi-faceted life. He was an academic for sure, including after he retired. But he was also a wine-maker, a friend to hundreds, a wood-worker, farmer, canoeist, camper, hunter, and traveler. He was modest, engaging and kind.”



Shaw’s career, Kraft said, “was a textbook example of the Wisconsin Idea – the notion that the boundaries of the university are the boundaries of the state," (Berry, Portage County Gazette).

Amazing!



I will continue to work for menstrual equality in Wisconsin.

My opponent Travis Tranel, like Scott Walker, is a member of the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). ALEC is  a corporate bill mill. It is not just a lobby or a front group; it is much more powerful than that. Through ALEC, corporations hand state legislators their wishlists to benefit their bottom line. Corporations fund almost all of ALEC's operations. They pay for a seat on ALEC task forces where corporate lobbyists and special interest reps vote with elected officials to approve “model” bills.
Not to be missed!
Some great news!

First off, I know I am not running against Glenn Grothman. But when I get his email updates, I am appalled. His recent actions to de-fund the EPA on a national level, closely mirror the cuts that have happened to our DNR. Thanks to Grothman's bill (HR5538), the EPA can no longer enforce new greenhouse gas regulations onto power plants or methane requirements onto the oil and gas industry. 



Additionally, the EPA will no longer be allowed to /monitor/control water on private land. How can that even be legal? If you own the land, you don't own the water. My Republican opponent for State Assembly has similar plans for WI. He voted to allow the DNR to sell naming rights for our state parks. He voted to prohibit the DNR review of high capacity wells. He voted to oppose developing clean energy and he removed local authority to protect water from pollution.



Who asked for this? Really. What small business, family or farm doesn't want clean water and clean air? A healthy economy needs healthy natural resources.

To all the candidates, both Republican and Democrat who didn’t just say that “something must be done”, didn’t just post on-line or complain rather they said “I must do something” and they got up and put themselves out there, got on the ballot, created a campaign team, spent time and treasure on their conviction that they could make Wisconsin and the Nation better, yet in spite of their best efforts someone else won tonight.  



I want to encourage you to join Sue and me in honoring those candidates and to commit tonight that starting tomorrow, we all do our part in aspiring to a higher level of political decorum, a higher level of statesmanship.  That starting tomorrow we realize that our opponents are our rivals, not our mortal enemies and that we lead our children in modeling respect for the individual and respect for authority.

  

We still live in the only nation where an orderly transition of power takes place on a regular basis, we have much more to be proud of than ashamed and much more to look forward to than to long for.

Earlier this morning I signed the Oath of Office to become an appointee to the Interstate Compact for Juveniles. As the DOC's website explains, "The Interstate Compact for Juveniles (ICJ) is an agreement between states that has the force of federal law. The ICJ provides for the cooperative supervision of juveniles on probation and parole who move across state lines. It also assists states in returning youth who run away, escape or abscond across state lines. An Interstate Commission for Juveniles, made up of a representative from each compacting state, promulgates rules to implement the compact and provides a forum to address new issues, enforce compliance with the rules, and collect and disseminate data."

It was with great sorrow that I learned of the untimely passing of Secretary Kitty Rhoades in June. Of course, she was held in the highest regard professionally. She spent her long and distinguished career making a difference for those less fortunate. 



It is so fitting that her family chose to honor her with a grant to eh Music & Memory Program; through them she is still giving to those in need. Kitty had such a loving heart. May she rest in peace, knowing that her legacy continues in the many lives she has touched.

"The Wisconsin Department of Justice environmental protection unit has shrunk to its smallest size in 25 years as state environmental regulators seek fewer fines from polluters.



Six attorneys were assigned to work in the unit last year compared to 10 as recently as 2008.



A Department of Justice spokesman said he couldn’t explain the trend, but attorneys who have worked closely with the unit said it may be a symptom of the dwindling number of pollution cases the state Department of Natural Resources has referred for legal action."

The organizing meeting of the Coordinated Campaign last night offered local Dems an upbeat diversion from the doom and gloom touted on our TVs from Cleveland. 



The theme of the night was "Stronger Together," and - it's true - the feeling of energy and power in that room was unmistakable. 



Democratic Party of Wisconsin Chair Martha Laning told the more than 70 in attendance that Wisconsin Dems are more than ready to turn the state blue in 2016 and beyond. She and the DPW have hired a young, energetic crew to help state legislative candidates (like yours truly) try to take back the Assembly and State Senate. 



Laning said our top-of-the-ticket candidates Russ Feingold and Hillary Clinton are poised to win big, as long as people at the grassroots level stay focused on the issues, and keep promoting core Democratic principals like fairness, equality, and a fair shake for working men and women.



"I know you've heard people say every year that 'this is the most important election,' but this time it's really true," Laning said,. "The stakes couldn't be higher." 



Kyle Whelton, Sheboygan's full-time Democratic field organizer, reminded the group that face-to-face contact is still the best way to win elections.  "Every positive contact you have with someone increases the chance by 10% that they will support your candidate," he said.  



Anyone interested in helping the Democratic Party between now and the election, should call Kyle at kwhelton@wivictory2016.org or 627-9082.

Join me and my fellow colleagues as we address reading proficiency in an active way!!  The new school year is just beginning and we are asking you to assist us by volunteering to read at a school in need.  There is an opportunity to make significant progress in our community by putting out a call to arms to all Milwaukee residents to join us in the fight against poverty by volunteering to read with children in our community schools with the greatest needs.



We are going to put our money where our mouth is and volunteer every week to read one on one with Milwaukee students that require reading assistance.  The percentage of Milwaukee 3rd graders reading proficiently is 15% district wide for school year 2013-14. We are pledging to make a positive impact and we ask that you join us.  If just one in twenty readers of this article accepts our challenge and volunteers for one hour a week, we will have over 670,000 hours of additional directed reading time in our community schools.



To volunteer, please contact either of us at Rep.Kooyenga@legis.wisconsin.gov or Rep.Goyke@legis.wisconsin.gov and we will help connect you with the school requesting your assistance.

Rep. Milroy Applauds UW-Superior Foundation on $25,000 Grant



MADISON- Representative Nick Milroy (D-South Range) congratulated the University of Wisconsin-Superior Foundation on its selection as a recipient of a $25,000 nonprofit grant from the Wisconsin Department of Veterans Affairs at a ceremony on Thursday, January 15. 



UW-Superior Foundation was awarded the grant during a ceremony at the State Capitol in Madison. The foundation was one of 25 nonprofit organizations that received grants to help support programs that provide services to Wisconsin veterans.  Representing the UW-Superior Foundation was Jason Young, Development Officer at UW-Superior. 



“As a veteran, I recognize the unique challenges that face servicemen and women as they transition back into civilian life,” said Milroy.  “I commend UW-Superior for ensuring that soldiers and veterans receive the support they need through the Veteran and Nontraditional Student Center.”



The University’s Veteran and Nontraditional Student Center provides a variety of academic support, career advisory, and campus engagement services to students who are active duty or veteran members of the armed forces and their families.



“Investing in education should always be a priority, and it is particularly important that we do everything we can to ensure that those who serve our country receive the help that they need as they begin the next chapter of their lives,” Milroy concluded.



(Photo Attached)

From left to right, Governor Scott Walker, Jason Young of UW Superior Foundation Office, Rep. Nick Milroy, Larry Kutschma of the Wisconsin Board of Veterans Affairs.

I was saddened to hear about the passing of Justice Patrick Crooks. Justice Crooks devoted his life to the service of others. He had a long and distinguished career as a Captain in the U.S. Army, an instructor of business law at the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay, and of course, his service on the bench of the Wisconsin Supreme Court since 1996. My thoughts and prayers are with his friends and family.

My office received an email yesterday evening from Outagamie County about some of the seasonal jobs that they are looking to fill this summer. These summer/seasonal positions will begin in May or June and last through the summer. Each position, except the lifeguard positions, require applicants to be 18+. 



Here are the Departments hiring and the open positions: 

Highway - Highway Worker, Office Assistant, Engineering Intern

Parks - Parks Worker, Lifeguard, Assistant to Naturalist

Recycling & Solid Waste - Grass Mowing, Office Assistant

Airport - Grass Mowing

MIS - MIS Intern

Land Conservation - Land Conservation Intern



If you are interested in one of these summer positions, fill out the application in this link, include which Department/position you are interested, and return it to the Human Resources Department.

I'm proud to be the lead author of the bill that would fully legalize marijuana in Wisconsin. 



Today I had the honor to speak at HarvestFest!



Good public policy often forms like a wave. It gathers momentum, at first with a ripple, then builds as congregating forces create something stronger. The policy finally crests when a critical mass is reached, and the politicians finally back the policy the public has been touting over time. Large pieces of legislation are passed when the people provide the momentum to create this wave.



Marijuana legalization is nearing this moment.

In November 1919, President Wilson proclaimed November 11 as the first commemoration of Armistice Day.  It wasn't until 1938  that "Armistice Day" was changed to "Veterans Day" to honor veterans of all wars.



Whereas the intent of Memorial Day is to honor and memorialize those who paid the ultimate price for our freedoms, Veterans Day is set aside to honor all of those who have served this country in the armed forces.



I would like to thank my late grandpa, Clarence Kremer (European Theater, WWII bugler and quartermaster), all of those who served with me in Kuwait and Iraq, my wife and family who supported my endeavors and all of those who have served and continue to serve our nation in an effort to protect everything that this great republic stands for - one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all!



Have a blessed Veterans Day tomorrow!

I am proud to have been named a Conservation Champion by the Wisconsin League of Conservation Voters for the second term in a row - a lifetime voting record of 100%.



WLCV knows that legislator can talk about the importance of clean drinking water, but for some reason – they don't all vote for it.



I know that Wisconsinites all over our great state cherish our clean air and water and the beautiful natural spaces we are graced with in our state. We understand that we are not truly free if the air we breathe and water we drink are polluted. Historically we have valued nature and all the things it provides us. Because of this, I am committed to continuing to be a Conservation Champion!

Here is an initiative that I'm proud to be a part of!



For Immediate Release            

Contact: Rep. Kulp (888) 534-0069

October 14, 2016   



Representative Kulp Pushes to Expand Rural Health Care Access

Madison – 



Earlier this week, Representative Bob Kulp (R-Stratford) joined 22 other rural area legislators from across the state to announce the second phase of the Rural Wisconsin Initiative.  



The Rural Wisconsin Initiative’s goal is to improve health care access for all parts of the state, including rural areas.



“We have a well-deserved reputation in Wisconsin for exceptional health care access. To continue in that route, we want to make sure we are investing even more in our rural areas.   The rural areas of the state are more vulnerable to shortages in health care access and workforce,” Rep. Kulp said. 



The Rural Wisconsin Initiative legislation was developed with input from the Wisconsin Hospital Association and other health care organizations from across the state, and will fund items such as residency programs for rural physicians, training consortia for allied health professionals, clinical training programs for Advanced Practice Clinicians, and wellness programs in rural areas.



“I believe this legislation will attract young health care professionals to work and train in rural communities.  In turn, they will be able to see how attractive the quality of life is here,” Rep. Kulp said.



To view the plan or offer suggestions, please visit www.RuralWisconsinInitiative.com

Hello everyone. Such sadness today. Sorry about the length of this post. I have been sitting here, since this morning, wondering how to respond. And words fail me. After 911, I was equally scared and angry. I grew up in New York, I have family members that served on the police force in NYC. And the next day, at the facility I was working at in central WI, we had about 40 second graders coming for a field trip. We were trying to go on as normally as possible, but the teachers, the staff and myself – we were all numb. How would anything be normal again after the attacks on the World Trade Center? What were these children thinking? How were they feeling? What would I say to them?



Miraculously, the words came to me, as we were doing our intro to the day. I told the students we knew some scary stuff happened yesterday. But I didn’t want them to be scared. We had the best people in the world working on this – police, firemen, volunteers. And they were working really hard to make things right. I asked them, if we could have a moment of silence, and just send our best thoughts to all the workers at Ground Zero. One child raised her hand and asked, “Can we pray?” I almost lost it. I said, yes. Send your prayers and your best happy thoughts to those people.



And now, the events of the past month across our nation have left me reeling again. I know it’s a beautiful day today in Sheboygan, and everyone I love is safe. But I still have this feeling nothing will ever be the same. We are so divided as a nation. We are our own worst enemy. And healing words fail me. 



So today, I was just sad. And that’s ok. If you want to be sad, or cry, we all deserve that. But not for long. After today, we must get to work. Building our communities, healing our neighborhoods. We have to get to know our neighbors, meet a new family at church, shake hands with a police officer, volunteer at your child’s school, voice your ideas on tolerance and education. I feel that sending good thoughts to those in charge was good for my second graders, but not good enough for the rest of us.



Like I said, I have family members that served on the police, and I know that the profession is a family. My heart goes out to the families of those police officers that were lost and injured in Dallas, and who are killed and injured every day, protecting us. But like every family, there are pockets of racism and ignorance. I know police departments across the country will be addressing this. Now we need to look at ourselves, our families. We must make sure we are practicing tolerance. 



To those black family members that have lost loved ones due to police shootings, I cannot pretend to know what you are going through or how you feel. But I am so, so sorry. And I can say, that as I run for elected office, I understand more than ever how important it is to be a voice for everyone. Especially for children. No child should have to live in an environment of fear and confusion. 



Things will never be the same. And as I write this, I can see that that is a good thing. We deserve change – change in leadership, change in attitude, and change in expectations. We must ensure a better future for our children, and stop these tragedies we have to explain but cannot find the words. We must advocate in everything we do, that all lives matter, regardless of race, creed, physical/cognitive ability, financial status, employment, political affiliation, or sexual orientation. Because that is the country I would like to wake up to. So, thank you for reading. And now, let’s get to work.

I know that voter suppression laws are being passed under the guise of election integrity. We know election integrity is not their real purpose. This is a coordinated, explicit attempt to suppress voters’ rights.



We must each pledge today to uphold our moral obligation to increase access to voting and to work toward a more fair society
If you or anyone you know experienced problems at the polls or with voter ID, please let us know.

The criminalization of non-violent, otherwise law-abiding marijuana users is crowding Wisconsin's prisons to a dangerous level. Too often, the jail to prison pipeline begins with a simple marijuana possession charge. This is costly and unnecessary for our state.



That is why I have introduced two bills to address the egregiousness of the current system. These pieces of legislation would provide for a Wisconsin that is safer, more free, and more prosperous.



LRB 3908 would make the penalty for second and subsequent marijuana offenses a misdemeanor with a fine of no more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than six months.



Additionally



LRB-3978 would allow a person who has a non-felony marijuana possession charge on their record to go to a court to get that record expunged if certain conditions are met, such as time since the conviction occurred.

State Representative Janel Brandtjen calls for funding cuts to Milwaukee until policies change:



For more information contact: June 7, 2016



Rep. Brandtjen- (414) 915-8425



Last week homeowners in Washington County were held hostage in their homes by the actions of 5 young criminals from Milwaukee. All night long the Milwaukee Police, SWAT teams and law enforcement from Washington County combed the darkness for 5 youths with guns. Families were forced to unlock their gun cabinets and instruct their loved ones to shoot to kill.



The violence and the crime that has plagued Milwaukee for decades has now begun to spill over into Milwaukee’s suburbs. I lay the responsibility for this growing and out of control problem at the door of the Mayor’s office. Mayor Barrett may not care about the safety of his family but I certainly do care about mine.



Mayor Barrett, the people of southeast Wisconsin will not sit by and watch your administration destroy the entire region with failed liberal policies and a 10 second “Tommy Tough Talk” sound bite. If you do not fill the hundreds of vacant police officer positions, apprehend and arrest car thieves, demand prison for repeat criminals and start standing up to the judges who let repeat offenders off easy you will be in my opinion “assisting and enabling” the very criminals who are responsible for the record number of shootings, car jacking’s and murders.



I will be openly advocating for funding cuts to Milwaukee unless steps are taken to dramatically cut crime in Milwaukee. I will no longer sit by while you destroy Milwaukee and its flourishing suburbs. I cannot justify financing your failed policies in Milwaukee until you take public safety seriously.



State Representative Janel Brandtjen.

The numerous activities that farmers, industry leaders and residents are undertaking to preserve the watershed of the Bay of Green Bay not only helps to conserve the world's largest freshwater lakes, but also helps to grow our economy. I applaud these efforts, and hope to continue searching for more public-private partnerships in the next Legislative session for the betterment of the economy and environment.

Work is still going on at the Capitol, even though we are out of session. I was appointed to serve on the Legislative Study Committee on Access to Civil Legal Services.The study committee is directed to review the funding and delivery of legal services for the indigent in civil cases.   



Why is this important?  



Led by Justice David Prosser, now retired, all seven members of the Wisconsin Supreme Court signed a letter requesting this study.  Civil cases can be anything from small claims to complicated family law, where individuals are trying to represent themselves because they cannot afford legal representation. This can cause bad outcomes for all of the parties involved, delays and wasted time by individuals and the courts.



Our constitution promises to "establish justice", and we pledge ourselves to be “one nation, under God, with liberty and justice for all.” The goal of this committee is to help realize our promises.

My press release opposing the bill to change the way the Chief Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court is selected: 



January 15, 2015                                                                                                                                  

Wachs Opposes Chief Justice Selection Proposal

AJR1 passes Judice Committee along party lines; proposed amendment by Dems fails



MADISON- On Thursday, January 15, the Assembly Committee on Judiciary passed Assembly Joint Resolution 1 (AJR1) by a vote of 5-3. This proposal is the second consideration of a constitutional amendment that would change the selection process for Supreme Court Chief Justice from the current system of seniority to a vote by members of the Court. If the proposal is adopted by the Legislature, it will have to be approved by a statewide referendum in the April election.



“This proposal is an invasion of the sovereignty of our Supreme Court,” said Rep. Dana Wachs (D-Eau Claire), ranking Democratic member of the Assembly Committee on Judiciary. “The supporters of this bill are clearly politically motivated and want to remove the current Chief Justice. The current system of selecting a justice has been in place for many years, and it is not the job of the Legislature to intervene. There is a separation of powers between the three branches of our government for a reason, and this proposal is an unprecedented attempt to disrupt the balance of power in Wisconsin.” 



Reps. Wachs, Gary Hebl (D-Sun Prairie) and Evan Goyke (D-Milwaukee) offered an amendment that would change the effective date to coincide with the end of the current Chief Justice’s term. This amendment was defeated on a party-line vote.



“We offered this amendment as a way for the supporters of the bill to demonstrate that their actions are not politically motivated,” added Wachs. “This amendment would also have circumvented procedural and substantive due process problems that this bill gives rise to. As passed, this bill in its application may violate rights afforded by the 5th and 14th Amendments to the United States Constitution. I am extremely disappointed in this vote, and I hope that my colleagues from across the aisle will seriously consider the ramifications of this action when the bill is brought before the full Assembly for a vote.”

Sparked on by a now-abandoned plan to restrict public access to legislative records, Assembly Democrats are calling for new rules on including policy items in the state budget bill.



The proposal from Assembly Assistant Democratic Leader Katrina Shankland (D-Stevens Point) would require any non-fiscal policy item in the budget to be referred to a standing Legislative committee, where it would have to receive a public hearing and executive session vote. During a Capitol press conference on Monday, Shankland said the change would “give our constituents and everyone around the state ample opportunity to first find out what’s in the legislation, and then…say whether or not they support the idea.”

UW System Promoting Excellent Veteran Education Services



University of Wisconsin System institutions have been setting an example for the nation by providing veterans and their families with supportive services to ensure a successful transition from military service to campus life.  To ensure continuity of services to veterans across all UW campuses, the UW System is creating the UW Veterans Education and Transition Success (VETS) Certification. This November the goals for UW VETS Certification will be determined by the U.S. Department of Education’s 8 Keys for Veteran Success, along with the members of the UW VETS Certifying Panel. The Kenosha school district is correct!



There is plenty of precedent, the recent 4th Circuit ruling notwithstanding (they refused to admit there is precedent from other courts), that Title IX does not address sex based on an individual's feelings.



Title IX clearly addresses sexual discrimination based on BIOLOGICAL differences between the sexes.



If Title IX addressed "sex" on the basis of one's perceived reality, then why in the world would Section 1686 of Title IX state:



"Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit any educational institution receiving funds under this Act, from maintaining separate living facilities for the different sexes."



(If you're really interested in pursuing this further, check out 120.12 (12) of Wisconsin statutes.)
