As the weather gets nicer in Wisconsin, we are celebrating our states flourishing tourism department. March 13-15th is the Wisconsin Governor’s Conference on Tourism in the Wisconsin Dells.



Tourism in Wisconsin had an $18.5 billion impact on the state’s economy in 2014, up $1 billion, or 5.5%, from $17.5 billion in 2013. The total four year growth of tourism activity is over $3.7 billion, a 25% increase from $14.8 billion in 2010. 



It is easy to see that tourism in Wisconsin means a great deal. This past budget we included a $500,000 increase to the tourism marketing department to continue attracting tourists to our great state and its attractions!

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 



Date: January 8, 2015

Contact: Melissa Sargent 

608-266-0960



Representative Sargent: Upskirting Bill Protects Privacy



MADISON - Last week, Representative Melissa Sargent (D-Madison) circulated a bill she co-authored with Representative Jim Ott (R-Mequon) for co-sponsorship. The bill addresses the issue of “upskirting”—using a camera or video recording device to take photos or videos up a person’s skirt or underneath a person’s clothing. 



Upskirting has become a significant problem in Wisconsin, but under current statutes, it is not a punishable offense.



“I was happy to work with Representative Ott to create a strong, bipartisan bill to address the growing issue of upskirting in Wisconsin. Advancements in technology require legislators to adapt and for our laws to evolve. I will continue to fight for the respect and protection of our citizens’ right to privacy and public safety.



Today, Representative Sargent testified on behalf of the legislation at a public hearing before the Judiciary Committee. If passed, the bill creates a felony offense for persons who knowingly take up skirting photos or videos of a person without their consent.



“No one should feel unsafe while doing everyday tasks like grocery shopping or riding the bus. Upskirting is an egregious violation of privacy and we must act swiftly to close this legislative loophole."

Recently, I sent a letter to our Congressional Delegation in support of the TREAT Act. “TREAT” stands for “The Recovery Enhancement for Addiction Treatment." This proposed federal act would expand access to treatment, including medication-assisted treatment, by lifting stringent federal regulations. Additionally, it would help increase the number of trained medical professionals that provide medication-assisted treatment. This change will save lives.

Below are the remarks that I gave earlier today to commemorate Memorial Day:



"Today, we remember the sons and daughters of our country who stood their ground in conflicts across the world and sacrificed their lives so that we may live in freedom. We display our gratitude by gathering together, decorating gravesites, and attending commemorations like this one. 



It’s difficult to speak on occasions like this, because those we are here to remember have already said so much. In their sacrifice, they spoke volumes, and demonstrated for us the purest form of love. The Bible says in John 15:13 that “Greater love hath no man than this - that a man lay down his life for his friends.” Wisconsin’s fallen veterans laid down their lives for their fellow soldiers, for their families and friends, and for millions of people that they never had the opportunity to meet on this earth. 



We honor the fallen by preserving their memories; memories not only of what they have done, but of who they were – committed men and women who passed away far too young. 



We remember them with moments of silence, when in our stillness we feel the weight of the gift that they have given to us. 

These moments of silence are important, but what’s more important is what happens after the silence. 



Recently, I read an essay prepared by the American Legion. The essay reflects on the question asked of many veterans “Was it worth it?” That’s a question that can only be answered by those who have served. The essay compels each of us, however to “Make it worth it.” 



So when the moment of silence is over, I want to encourage each of you to “live life out loud”. Dare to dream big and do great things. Get involved in your community. Prioritize patriotism over politics. Make a difference. We owe it not only to ourselves, but to those who sacrificed their lives so that we could live in a free and peaceful society – one that affords each of us so many opportunities.  



In America, it is traditional to celebrate all veterans on Veterans Day, and those who died in service to our country on Memorial Day. However, in closing, I want to blur the lines a bit. We can honor the sacrifice of those who have fallen by taking the time to care about their comrades who are still with us. 22 veterans commit suicide every day.  These casualties can be prevented. Be there for the veterans in your life – and for their families; listen to them, and support them. 



I would encourage you to seek out charities like the Honor Flights, Operation Homefront, or the Fisher House that work to ensure our veterans have access to the resources, care, and recognition that go beyond what the government provides. 



Thank you for the privilege of addressing you today. May God bless each of you, and those who have went before."

Debbie Bork's dad, Leo L. Molumby, U.S. Navy. Fought in WWII, in the Aleutian Islands. Rate/Rank: EM3 Electricians Mate Third Class.



Leo never spoke much about the war, but one detail he did share was that his ship was hit & he ended up in the water. Many died. He was in the water for 2-3 days; this was in the Aleutian waters. Cold. He was the only survivor, grateful to make it back to the U.S. Later blessed to marry and have a family.

Job announcements - Milwaukee area  

 

Bilingual YoungStar Technical Consultant

The Wisconsin Early Childhood Association Milwaukee office is seeking a full-time, bilingual (Spanish and English speaking) technical consultant who will be responsible for working with regulated family child care and group center programs to provide objective, evidence-based feedback about key indicators of quality related to environments, curriculum, and business practices.  This position involves frequent travel within Milwaukee County.   

 

This position requires a Bachelor's Degree in Early Childhood (or related field), and a minimum of 4 years' experience in the Early Education field. Expertise in early childhood program assessments (ERS, CLASS, and/or PAS and BAS), WMELS, and early education curriculum development is preferred.    

 

Qualified candidates are encouraged to apply indicating minimum salary requirements. Competitive salary and benefits.  WECA is an AA/EO Employer. Send cover letter and resume by January 28, 2015 to: WECA, Attn: HR-Technical Consultant, 744 Williamson Street, Suite 200, Madison WI  53703 or email HR@wisconsinearlychildhood.org. No phone calls, please.   

 

 

YoungStar Formal Rater

Wisconsin Early Childhood Association is seeking a full-time formal rater from/near the Southern (Southeastern area preferred) portion of Wisconsin. This rater will be responsible for providing objective, evidence-based quality ratings to regulated family, group, and school age child care programs, primarily using the Environment Rating Scales. These positions work remotely, out of the home, and involve frequent, sometimes overnight travel across the state. 



This position requires a Bachelor's Degree in Early Childhood (or related field), and a minimum of 4 years' experience in the Early Education field. Expertise in early childhood program assessments (ERS, CLASS, and/or PAS and BAS), WMELS, and early education curriculum development is preferred.   

 

Qualified candidates are encouraged to apply indicating minimum salary requirements. Competitive salary and benefits.  WECA is an AA/EO Employer. Bilingual (Spanish or Hmong preferred) and ethnically diverse individuals are encouraged to apply. Send cover letter and resume by January 28, 2015 to: WECA, Attn: HR-Formal Rater, 744 Williamson Street, Suite 200, Madison WI  53703 or email HR@wisconsinearlychildhood.org. No phone calls, please.     

 

 

Professional Development Counselor

The Wisconsin Early Childhood Association Milwaukee office is seeking applicants for a 100% time Professional Development Counselor, preferably Spanish-bilingual, for the YoungStar Quality Rating Program.  

 

This position provides professional development guidance and case management in the form of academic, non-academic and career counseling. Bachelor's Degree in Early Childhood Education or related field, work experience in the early childhood field, good communication skills, and computer literacy required.  Candidates must have demonstrated ability to work with and understand culturally diverse populations. 

 

Competitive salary and benefits.  WECA is an AA/EO Employer.  Bilingual, ethnically diverse individuals are encouraged to apply. Send cover letter and resume by January 28, 2015 to: WECA, Attn: HR - Professional Development, 744 Williamson Street, Suite 200, Madison, WI 53703 or email HR@wisconsinearlychildhood.org. No phone calls, please.

FROM THE DNR:

Natural Resources Board approves 2016 deer harvest quotas and season structure

 

The Wisconsin Natural Resources Board approved deer hunting season framework and antlerless deer quotas for 2016 at its May 25 meeting in Madison. Final season framework reflects recommendations from County Deer Advisory Councils.

 

Ten deer management units will not have an antlerless quota (each within the Northern and Central Forest zones), while the rest of Wisconsin will have a quota of 256,775 antlerless deer (compared to 224,735 in 2015).

 

A Holiday Hunt will be held in 13 counties and provide for an additional antlerless-only opportunity for firearm hunters from Dec. 24 to Jan.1. In addition, junior license holders in Ashland, Sawyer and Forest counties will not be allowed to harvest antlerless deer – these councils exercised their right to submit this recommendation in an effort to encourage increased herd growth.

 

As a reminder, bonus antlerless permit sales for the Forest zones begin Monday, Aug.15 at 10 a.m. Central Farmland Zone permits will go on sale Aug. 16, and Southern Farmland Zone bonus permits will be made available Aug. 17.



The department’s deer hunting webpage will be updated within the coming weeks with a number of helpful resources regarding hunting 2016 quotas and season framework. For more information, including an updated carcass tagging FAQ, search keyword “deer.”

Celebrate Flag Day



Today, June 14, is Flag Day a holiday that commemorates the adoption of the flag of the United States by the Second Continental Congress in 1777. On Flag Day citizens are urged to fly the American flag and celebrate all that it represents, freedom, liberty and democracy, and national pride. 2016 marks the 100th anniversary of Flag Day, which was first officially celebrated in 1916 by a proclamation of President Woodrow Wilson. 



Take a few moments today to celebrate our nation’s flag and the values that make our country great.

SO MANY MYTHS, SO LITTLE TIME -- This idea that Wisconsin is a high tax state has driven the right wing's drive to drive our state into the ground.



Well, carry this fact. 



It isn't. As usual the right lives in a fantasy world of their own making, but they have done a very good job of selling people on the idea that high taxes/high spending are "facts" as they have done on so many issues.



In fact someone did an analysis a few years back and found that the business groups in every state claimed that the taxes in their state were the highest. Well, well.



But because people have been lured onto these rocks by the Sirens of the right, we are not seeing fat cut in this state but muscle and bone.



Want to fight back? Spread this around LIBERALLY.

Representative Bowen released the following statement about the proposed "Blue Day Rally" happening at the Bavarian Bierhaus in Glendale this Sunday featuring Gov. Walker and members of the City of Milwaukee Common Council:



"It is critical with the consistent situations of disproportionate black citizens killed by the unnecessary use of lethal force by law enforcement that this upcoming police support event being attended by various political leaders, including our own Governor, highlight the need for police accountability in order to prevent future incidents rooted in the disregard of the value of black lives. Governor Walker and others who stand with him have a tremendous opportunity to prove that they are finally listening to the concerns of many around our state who believe that both the Police and the citizens that they serve deserve the chance to live and make it back home to their families. Dontre Hamilton, a mentally ill young black man who was shot 14 times by a Milwaukee Police Officer 6 miles from where the event will be held, deserved the chance to make it back home to his family. 



Not recognizing the need for the call for police accountability would be detrimental to the progress that must be made to end the frustrations that many black families have when they, too, worry if their sons and daughters, fathers and mothers will make it back home safely after interaction with Police. This event will probably be used as a political platform to tell a captive Police audience what they may want to hear but it has the potential be used a support platform to tell them what they need to hear. What the whole state needs to hear. That Black Lives must matter and those who advocate for them need their support too."

This is an editorial about a press event Ron Kind and I spoke at recently.

This isn't just about Scott Walker, it's about every single Republican in the Wisconsin state legislature who, lock-step and single-mindedly, with little to no thought, march along with him.  Former Representative Mary Williams is guilty, as is the current Republican who refuses to represent what the PEOPLE want.  Jimmy Boy has got to go!



This is the truth behind the Republican lie.  I hope you read it.  Feel free to ask me questions.  I'll be happy to answer!



From one of the comments at the end of the article, which sums it all up nicely:

"All we’ve heard from Walker and the Republican legislators is that overpaid and over benefited public employees were the cause of the budget problems that required Act 10. Looking at these charts those claims weren’t truthful as most of us tried to explain to the people of Wisconsin. All of Walker’s disparaging and denigrating language directed at public employees was not based in fact and were lies designed to turn people against public employees to support his hostile actions. It was all for one reason; to destroy public employee unions by turning people against their public servants in classic “DIVIDE and Conquer!” Later in his reign of terror he did the same thing to private unions. In the process he has driven Wisconsin’s economy, education and environment in to the tank. We are now a low wage, low jobs, low opportunity state with poverty and economic hardship for most becoming the norm."

BREAKING NEWS: CHANGES TO WRS REMOVED FROM BUDGET



As many of you know, the JFC approved a measure on Thursday that would make serious changes to the Legislative Committee that oversees the Wisconsin Retirement System (WRS). Now on its own, this doesn’t sound like much but this provision would remove the lawmakers and public member only to replace them with politicians. In other words, this measure looked like they were preparing to stack the deck in case they want to make changes to the WRS. The Senate just announced that these changes will be removed from the budget entirely and it is my hope that this will also be the case in the Assembly.



----



Well, I hope you all enjoyed the fireworks this weekend because there are fireworks going on inside the Capitol right now. Remember that ‘budget deal’ that was announced on Wednesday that would end the stalemate? It seems to have ignited a bit of a firestorm.



On Thursday, the Joint Finance Committee finally met to finish their work of redrafting the budget. One of the things that happens on the last day of this process is the introduction of “Budget Motion 999.” This is a term for the final catch-all motion for all sorts of items that the JFC decided to add to the budget at the very last minute. It usually passes in the middle of the night and the rest of us wake up to find that something that would never have been approved in the light of day was snuck into the large motion.



And that is exactly what happened in the wee hours of Friday morning.



The JFC voted to make dramatic changes to Wisconsin’s open records law. For those of you who aren’t familiar with this, the open records law allows anyone to request information from their state lawmakers, local officials and their offices. But under this proposal in “Budget Motion 999,” this method of open government and transparency would be sharply curtailed. 



This measure quickly incited a public outcry and all the majority members of the JFC claimed they didn’t know who came up with the idea after they all voted to approve it. And unfortunately, “Budget Motion 999” was written in a way that makes it almost impossible to find out who proposed each change.



On Monday, a Republican member of the JFC publically apologized for his voters for voting for such dramatic changes to our open records law. Apparently he didn’t understand the full scope of what was being proposed. Now, I understand that a lot of what we deliberate in Madison is complicated but it is vital to ensure that you have all the facts before casting a vote in the middle of the night on something that had little to no public input.



After so many people got upset about this measure, it was quickly pulled out of the budget. But that didn’t stop the Assembly leadership from attempting to defend the merits of the proposal. One of them even dropped a swear word during an interview. Like I said, fireworks. 



Thanks to the hundreds of Wisconsinites who wrote, called or emailed with their concerns, this measure is now safely out of the budget. Sometimes “we the people” can make a difference.



So where does this leave us? Well, as we speak, the Senate is debating the budget and the Assembly will take it up tomorrow. This appears to be another sign of a turf war between the Assembly and the Senate as they fight to see who gets to go first. The Senate says they will include a full repeal of the prevailing wage law in the budget, which goes against the deal that was announced on Wednesday to leave it out of the budget entirely. Things are changing so quickly that it is all we can do to try to stay on top of it. 



For those of you who are nerdy like me or wonky enough to want to see some of the nitty gritty numbers behind the budget, check out this memo put together by the Legislative Fiscal Bureau (LFB). It gives a nice rundown of the differences between the budget that the Governor originally proposed back in February and the budget approved by Joint Finance Committee last week.

I'm so excited and proud of local musician Gaelynn Lea Tressler, winner of NPR's tiny desk contest. I can't wait to hear her NPR concert. 



I first saw Gaelynn play several years ago at the Thirsty Pagan in Superior with Alan Sparhawk of the band Low. Alan is a musical genius and, in my opinion, the most successful musician that the Twin Ports has seen since Bob Dylan. He discovered Gaelynn playing at a local farmers market and asked her if she'd like to play with him in a band called Murder of Crows. Since that time she has worked with Alan and a recently added looping to her repertoire. Last summer I saw her play solo at North Country Independent Living's annual expo and it was evident that she had come a long way since her early days playing with Alan. Her confidence and skill has matured and she now is making uniquely beautiful music that will now be heard by a much wider audience. The Twin Ports is home to a music scene unrivaled by cities of similar populations. I feel very lucky to live here and support these local musicians. I have no doubt that Gaelynn will continue to inspire and grow our local music scene as she brings her talent to the national stage.

Today Suzie and I made our way to the Capitol, where we joined with several thousands of friends to express ourselves. We met the Guenthers, Rita Pulver and Sandy Henney, Margarete Worthington, Chuck Kalina, Chris Taylor, Melissa Sargent, Jeff Smith and others from our campaign, and from other campaigns waged for the people of Wisconsin. There was a great deal of energy, and righteous anger. Above all there was a sense of dogged detrmination and commitment to the long haul. We know that the bad ideas and damaging policies advanced by the regressive faction in power will fail, and whether that be sooner or later, the tide will turn. History and the will of the people is against the regressive, repressive right. The power of the people united will prevail over the narrow interests of the few.Here are a few snapshots.

It is a privilege to be endorsed by the leading voice of the working class family and I will be taking the responsibility of this endorsement very seriously. Yesterday an attack at Green Bay Correctional resulted in three correctional workers being stabbed and beaten. My dad is a third generation civil servant who is employed at a state correctional facility. Our correctional facilities are overpopulated and understaffed, putting our civil servants in greatly compromised situations. 



So when I see news of these attacks I don't just see a faceless state worker, I see my dad. It sickens me that our state government has taken away the rights of these hard working men and women to collectively bargain for safer working conditions. Without a doubt, one of my biggest goals is to repeal Act 10 with and restore the rights of the working class.

With Harold "Diz" Kronenberg at the "Honor and Remember" Golf outing for Veterans held at Hickory Hills golf course.  Diz organized this event 11 years ago.  At the banquet (at which I had the honor of singing) Diz was presented with the French Liberty Medal and also the French Medal of Honor. Diz served in the United States Air Force during World War II as a tail gunner in a B-17 bomber, flying in 42 successful bombing missions over Europe.  It is a distinct honor and privilege to call Diz a personal Friend.  I extend the thanks of our entire State and Nation for the incredible selfless service of this amazing Gentleman!

My wife and I are proud farmers raising our family here in Kewaunee County. We know the strengths and struggles of this community because we live them every day. The reality is that our home has long depended on Kewaunee Power Station to balance its budget, which we can no longer do. As neighbors, we must rally together to keep our home and heritage strong. It's time to diversify our economy and tax base by creating a community that will attract young families, entrepreneurs and a robust tourist economy. Together, we will ensure a strong future for Kewaunee County and the whole of District 1. Will you join me?



#HometownPride #Collaborate #livelocal #votelocal

Representative Dave Considine (D-Baraboo) offered the Democratic Weekly Radio Address on the serious ongoing problems at the state Department of Corrections and Democratic efforts to solve them.



Rep. Considine said: "The Walker Administration and some Republican legislators have known about these problems for a long time but have neglected to take any meaningful action to solve them. We need to support and protect our hardworking corrections officers and staff, as well as our inmates. And we need to work to bring all members of our Wisconsin community together and build a more productive and safe society."

The Speaker's Task Force on Urban Education will hold a public hearing on issues related to early childhood education on Tuesday, January 26, from 1 p.m. until 7 p.m. 



The hearing will begin with invited testimony from Dr. Darienne Driver, Superintendent of Milwaukee Pubilc Schools, followed by testimony from representatives of Milwaukee Succeeds, United Way, Children's Hospital of Wisconsin, the Wisconsin Department of Children and Families, and Milwaukee Education Partnership.



The task force will welcome public testimony following the conclusion of invited testimony.



I hope you will have the opportunity to attend!

*** Polls are open 7 am - 8 pm on Election Day. If you are in line at 8pm, you can still vote!

Estimados amigos,                                      Bienvenidos a la pagina de mi campana. Me llamo Mariana Herrera Stout. Soy hija de inmigrantes Hispanos que empezaron emigrar de Texas a el estado de Wisconsin desde la primer parte de los anos  de1960. Mi familia completa trabajo en los campos de las ciudades de East Troy y Palmyra. El 11 de noviembre de 1967 mi madre murio en el campo de East Troy. Me cree con sus padres en un pueblito al Sur Este del estado de Wisconsin que le llaman Darien. Soy de raices humildes. Mi primer casa de infancia previsto alojamientos para diez y siete familiares total. Deseo ganar el puesto de Assembly en el districto 56 por cual me haigo en competicion. Seria un honor representar los derechos de todos sin respeto a raza, color, modo de vivir o religion igualmente. Les pido la oportunidad de ganarme su confianza y su voto el dia 8 de noviembre 2016. Muchas gracias.

Our friend, Donald Ystad of Rome, has another brilliant email out sent to his list of public officials and stakeholders in central Wisconsin. My opponent and all policymakers need to listen to Donald. Not protecting our water is madness.



Fellow concerned citizens,



Many of you attended the citizen meeting in Rome in January when Dr. George Kraft told us we knew a lot about phosphorous in our water, quite a bit about nitrates in our water, but very little about the effect of pesticides in our water. He said the science isn't there yet, especially where it concerns the complex mix of chemicals in many pesticides.



I think you should read this, and be aware where our groundwater recharge area is.  It is east and north towards Town of Grant, Leola, and Plainfield, some of the most heavily cropped acreage in the area, and the area where we've seen hundreds of acres clear cut and converted to crop fields this year. I don't mean to alarm you, but this article talks of Atrizine showing up in drinking water 20 years after it was banned. It also talks of politicians trying to reverse it's ban stating it would be a hardship on farmers, even though it is completely banned in Europe. It would be interesting to follow the money and see who contributes to these politicians campaigns.  Wisconsin’s current groundwater law does not set a standard for total pesticides in water, nor is there a standard set nationally by the EPA. The European Union’s standard is 0.5 ppb.



What do we do? In Rome, about 1/3 of us are on Rome municipal water. They test every three years for things like pesticides and are scheduled for a full cycle next year. For all of us who may be concerned about the lack of control of these chemicals and the effect on our groundwater, we need to express our concern to DATCP, the Department of Trade and Consumer Protection, benbrancel@wisconsin.gov & Stan.Senger@wisconsin.gov, and to the DNR, as they also conclude we have an issue with pesticides, cathy.stepp@wisconsin.gov. While politicians are blowing in their ear to induce them to loosen restrictions, we need to be in their other ear, reminding them who they work for.



Don

As a lover of the outdoors and Wisconsin's state parks, and a member of the Assembly Committee on Natural Resources and Sporting Heritage, I'm very concerned about the budget proposals mentioned in this article. I hope the Joint Finance Committee will restore funding for our state parks, the Stewardship Program, and DNR staff, and maintain the authority of the DNR board. Wisconsin's natural resources and public lands are a treasure for our own residents and visitors from other states. We should not be putting that in jeopardy with this shortsighted budget proposal.

This morning, my colleagues on the Joint Finance Committee (Sens. Darling & Vukmir and Reps. Nygren & Knudson) announced we will not be taking the Governor’s proposal on long-term care changes, but will be looking to make limited reforms with legislative oversight. We are proposing to remove the Governor’s changes to FamilyCare and IRIS, but directing DHS to apply for a federal waiver for changes on FamilyCare to integrate long-term care and medical care.  The proposal will be required to include:

- Require public and stakeholder input before any changes are made.

- Require self-directed care with budget authority, to be defined in statute.

- Require a regional model with multiple Integrated Health Agencies (IHA) per region.

- Require an independent actuarial study to set rates.

- Require the acceptance of “any willing provider” for a multi-year transition.

 -Preserve ADRC services.

- Require final approval of any waiver application by the Joint Finance Committee before submission to the Federal Government.

IN-DISTRICT TOWN HALLS:

With the budget finished and the fall legislative session right around the corner, I will be holding four town hall meetings to receive feedback from constituents and to answer any questions or concerns they may have.



Earlier this year, I was able to hold several listening sessions which focused on the budget. Those listening sessions were very useful to me over the course of the budget process and I trust these town halls will prove just as helpful for the upcoming fall session. I encourage residents of the Fox Cities to attend and if anyone is unable, you are always welcome to contact me by phone, email, or letter.



I will be available to meet with constituents at the locations and times listed below:



Town of Menasha Listening Session #1

Where: Town of Menasha Town Hall, Town Council Chambers, 2000 Municipal Drive, Neenah

Neenah Listening Session #1

I support the legalization of medicinal marijuana. It's pain relieving effects and anti-inflammatory properties are well documented. Countless individuals have publicly reported it's efficacy in use for treatment of pain. And families with no hope of ever finding any drug to help curb their children's seizures are reporting it's use and effects as nothing short of a godsend. Experts researching it's use for treating Post Traumatic Stress are seeing highly favorable outcomes. And many veteran's suffering from this disorder are  reporting that it has helped them alleviate their suicidal thoughts. The negative effects often reported when using pharmaceutical drugs are also non existent. Shouldn't our goal be to provide our fellow man with the most effective, least harmful treatments for illness? As a civilized nation we owe it to those who suffer the ability to access and use marijuana as treatment free from the risk of legal intervention and indictment.

Deer Trustee Report permanent rule public comment form now available online; Deadline January 31st



To help gather feedback regarding the proposed Deer Trustee Report permanent rule, an online public input form is now available to gather public comments. People can complete an input form by searching the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources website, dnr.wi.gov, for keyword "deer." The form will remain open for public comment until 12:00 a.m. February 1, 2015. 



New regulations and programs, including the Deer Management Assistance Program, were set up under an emergency rule in 2014, and now a follow-up permanent rule package is necessary for the 2015 hunting seasons and beyond.



While the public input form provides an opportunity to submit feedback online, nine public hearings will also be held throughout Wisconsin over the next week. Hearing dates and locations are as follows - each will run from 6-8 p.m.:



Tuesday, Jan. 20

• La Crosse - DNR Service Center, Room B19, 3550 Mormon Coulee Road

• Fitchburg - DNR Service Center, Gathering Waters Conference Room, 3911 Fish Hatchery Road. 



Wednesday, Jan. 21

• Dodgeville - DNR Service Center, Conference Room, 1500 N. Johns St. 



Thursday, Jan. 22

• Chippewa Falls - Chippewa Valley Technical College Business Education Center, Room 103A, 620 West Clairemont Ave.

• Green Bay - Northeast Wisconsin Technical College, Lecture Hall Room SC132, 2740 W. Mason St.

• Schofield - DC Everest Middle School, Auditorium, 9302 Schofield Ave. 



Monday, Jan. 26

• Waukesha - DNR Service Center, Room 151 (West entrance), 141 NW Barstow St.; and 

• Spooner - Spooner DNR Service Center, Community Room, 810 West Maple St. 



Tuesday, Jan. 27

• Rhinelander - James Williams Middle School auditorium, 915 Acacia Lane. 



The Natural Resources Board will consider feedback submitted online, along with comments from January public hearings, when making its final decision on the proposed permanent rule package on Feb. 25. If approved, the rule package will advance to the state legislature for final review.



For more information regarding hearing locations and the Deer Trustee Report, visit dnr.wi.gov and search keywords "hearings" and "deer trustee report" respectively.



FOR MORE INFORMATION CONTACT: Scott Loomans, regulations specialist, Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources, (608) 267-2452

Today I released the following statement in light of recent killings of black citizens at the hands of Law Enforcement in Wisconsin and around the Country and the shooting attack on Dallas police officers and protesters last night: 



“At times there are clear reasons to give up hope that we as a community and a nation might treat Black citizens equally and equitably to their White brothers and sisters who engage with law enforcement and live on to make it back home to their families. Whether it’s a conversation, a verbal warning, a ticket, or an arrest, every person deserves the chance to get to that next step in the process. The same goes for officers who are committed to serving our residents. Every time they clock in for a shift, they deserve the chance to clock out and return to their families. No one deserves to have his or her life taken in situations that can be prevented with other courses of action.



“This could be one of those times. We all are contemplating if this is too hard to solve and heal. But giving up means giving up on ourselves and the brighter and better future our community and our country deserve. This added trauma and heightened tension prevents us from building authentic, positive relationships between our communities of color and law enforcement committed to the safekeeping of our community.



“Just two weeks ago Jay Anderson, a 25 year old black man, was sitting in his car in a suburban Milwaukee park when he was approached by a police officer who shot him to death after seeing a gun in the car. On Tuesday Alton Sterling, a 37 year old black man from Baton Rouge, Louisiana, was shot to death while pinned down on the ground and a gun was discovered. And on Wednesday in a suburb of St. Paul, Minnesota Philando Castile, a 32 year old black man, was pulled over on a routine traffic stop for a broken tail light and shot to death with a child and girlfriend in the car.



“At the same time, last night’s horrific situation in Dallas of 12 Police Officers & 2 protesters injured from a shooting attack that left five officers dead is another obstacle that keeps us from working and engaging in dialogue with each other. This is not what we need.



“Real, authentic relationships between law enforcement and the communities they serve will be built if we rise above the pressure to give up and focus on addressing problems and distractions. Clearly, we can’t afford not to any longer.



“I pray for all the families and all heavy hearts hurt from these situations. May God help us.”



***

Farmer Jones had 100,000 eggs and big dreams. He decided to make a down payment on that new John Deere he had his eye on. He figured that the money he could get from selling all those chickens would be more than enough to pay for the tractor.



But guess what — not all of his eggs hatched. Now Farmer Jones risks losing the farm over his bad decision. Perhaps he hadn’t heard that saying about counting his chickens before they hatched.



Unfortunately, our leaders in Madison missed that lesson, too.

"And what he greatly thought, he nobly dared." - Homer



I knew field organizer Kyle Welton was someone special the first time I met him, and he recited from memory a long passage from Homer's The Illiad. He studied it at Marquette, Kyle explained, and the Greek classic has inspired him ever since.



Thanks to Kyle's persuasive, non-stop recruiting, dozens (hundreds?) of Sheboygan area Dems are spending thousands of hours on the phone, on the streets and in public places everywhere, telling voters what's at stake in this election. It's a larger and more enthusiastic group than I've ever seen here, and it's beautiful. 



I'm grateful to those who secured the finding to open two local offices and to hire Kyle, who has turned both places into such hotbeds of activity.



I stopped in on a recent evening and watched him make a few of his recruiting calls.  The place was deserted at that late hour, but there he was, making call after call. His goal is 200 calls every night, he told me. This takes a minimum of four hours.



Thanks, Kyle, for working all those hours, and for inspiring me to make my own calls. I can't top 200, but I'll do what can, and I won't give up.  



It's never been more important for Progressives to think great thoughts. And nobly dare.

I said I would write my thoughts on the events around Sherman Park and the hours I spent there yesterday and last night, here it is:



Bricks and Energy. 



The same energy that's used to pick up a brick, and throw it through a window is...

The same energy that's used to pick up a brick, and put it on top of another brick lined with mortar. 

The same energy that's used to destroy is...

The same energy that's used to build.



My Rabbi once told me anger is favorable to depression because depression is not only a lack of energy, but an active void sucking energy into a blackhole of nothingness. Whereas Anger is energy, true enough manifesting itself in a negative way, but energy nonetheless. That energy has the potential to be transformed into something positive, and in that there lies hope.



As I was driving back to the Sherman Park area, well...I'd be lying if I said I didn't feel nervous. I heard stuff was getting tense and might be poppin off real soon, but this is my city, my community and if it's suffering I'm suffering too. I texted some friends so they knew exactly where I was, I called another friend who was over there and he told me "Just be careful, you're white and some people are being irrationally violent". As I drove up I saw the cops in full force, I saw the lights blaring, and the crowds waiting for something to happen, it was getting ready to potentially go down. 



I parked on Sherman, off of Burleigh, and looked around...I saw lots of guns with fingers on triggers, lots of military-looking gear, lots of scared, curious, angry, and tired people. I saw a group of dudes walk by me, eye me up, and say something like "We burning this MF to the ground tonight." Then the group marching west down Burleigh showed up and they came to the intersection. Lots of "No Justice No Peace" chants and "Whose Streets? Our Streets!". After a few mins things started getting a little hairy.. There was a small group (I don't think more than 30 or so of the 500 plus people who were there) that started throwing rocks, bottles, and bricks. It was at this point the police really went into action. Bus load after bus load from north and south of Burleigh on Sherman started showing up and unloading heavily armored cops. More stuff was thrown (I almost got hit a few times) and the crowd started dispersing quickly. We went across the street, out of the target area, and I met up with some other friends, reporters, onlookers, community members, and neighborhood leaders and we watched, talked, and waited together. 



We then walked further down to see what was going on a little bit west of us, and ran into another friend who happens to be a DJ, and he kept saying how he just is seeing more and more friends out tonight. I mentioned that in another context, with those cop lights as strobe lights, his equipment instead of the cops blow-horns and all our friends out here this could be a very different night. He got it right away and we briefly entertained the idea of a late night block party and what that could look like. Things seemed to settle down a bit and I left around midnight or so, but I want you to take a moment and think about that brief interaction with my DJ friend.  



That's just the point, isn't it? The energy there was unmistakable and heavy in the air...BUT that same energy could be a "riot" or a block party, a window being smashed or a home being built. We can try and repress the energy, try and lock more people up, instill more curfews, penalize people further, and try to depress that energy, OR we can engage our community and our youth, work to TRANSFORM that energy into something greater, something positive, and something we can all be proud of. 



Instead of the hate, the finger pointing, and the anger, let's work to elevate our community and the energy within it for something greater than what we are seeing now.

Mayor Barrett and the Milwaukee Common Council vote today on the Streetcar project. Yesterday, I wrote them to express the importance of voting in favor of its development.



The construction and operation of the Streetcar would provide both short and long term job creation for our community. The bulk of the capital needed to grow this project will be provided through federal funding sources and would be passed to other states or cities if not utilized here. 

 

The Streetcar will attract a fresh workforce and new businesses. It provides another environmentally friendly option to satisfy our city’s transportation needs and a safe ride option for people returning home after community events. 

 

I support the proposed Streetcar because it makes sense as part of a larger growth strategy for Milwaukee. I hope today's vote is in favor of this valuable investment.

As a State Representative, I have the opportunity to go to a lot of different ceremonies. But the thing that always sticks out about Eagle Scout Ceremonies is that these young men aren't just being recognized for improving themselves, they are being celebrated for improving our community. It takes 100 hours of community service to achieve the rank of Eagle Scout. 



Nick and Alex Shupe joined the elite ranks of the Eagle Scouts on Sunday, October 2nd. For their projects, Alex planned and constructed the reindeer shelter at Rotary Lights and Nick planned and constructed the candy cane posts at Rotary Lights.



Congratulations to you both and thank you for allowing me to participate in this wonderful event.

LAB and Audit Committee Are Important for Legislative Oversight



MADISON – Today, the co-chairpersons of the Joint Legislative Audit Committee responded to a legislative proposal that would eliminate the nonpartisan Legislative Audit Bureau (LAB) and the Joint Legislative Audit Committee by indicating their strong support for and confidence in the quality work of LAB and the professionalism of LAB staff.



Through its audit work with the Joint Legislative Audit Committee, LAB supports the Legislature’s oversight of state agencies by identifying instances or patterns of fraud, statutory noncompliance, waste, and mismanagement. LAB identifies ways state agencies can achieve cost savings and realize efficiencies. LAB also provides policy analysis to inform legislative action on specific programs or more generally across state government.



“For nearly 50 years, audits performed by the Legislative Audit Bureau have been a legislative ‘check’ on state agencies and programs,” said Representative Samantha Kerkman (R-Salem).  That the Audit Bureau performs its work externally to state agencies and in a non-partisan manner is crucial to its findings and to the value we place in its work.”



LAB identifies concerns, areas for cost savings, and policy information through its Fraud, Waste, and Mismanagement Hotline, which protects the identity of informants by statute.



“The non-partisan Legislative Audit Bureau is an invaluable resource to the Legislature and to the people of the state,” said Sen. Robert Cowles. “Our auditors provide insight and proactive recommendations to the Legislature and state agencies that help to protect Wisconsin taxpayers by locating cost saving measures and efficiencies.”



Senator Robert Cowles and Representative Samantha Kerkman (R-Salem), co-chairpersons of the Joint Legislative Audit Committee, produced a list of selected noteworthy findings from LAB audits, which accompanies this press release.



More information about the work of LAB and the Joint Legislative Audit Committee is available at www.legis.wisconsin.gov/lab.

Archbishop Timothy Dolan, on Catholicism and Abortion, "If the baby in the womb can be sucked out and left dead, with healthcare workers coerced to perform the hideous procedure and all of us forced to pay for it; if the physically challenged and mentally depressed can pay their doctor to put them to death; if the immigrant is caricatured as a criminal and threat; if women are looked upon as chattel whose main purpose is to be groped and satisfy a leering man; if the human person’s first and most cherished freedom — religion — is mocked and reduced to bigotry; if black lives and blue lives are considered enemy targets rather than sacred individuals; if a climate of political correctness keeps us from calling radical fundamentalists the psychopathic murderers they are … well, then, human life is treated as rubbish, which can be eliminated to suit our preferences.



Am I wrong to wonder especially about the toxic effect that the unlimited abortion license has had on the Republic founded on self-evident truths, and the right to life? When what should be nature’s safest sanctuary, the mother’s womb, becomes the most perilous place for the most innocent and fragile life, should we be shocked when any life deemed “in the way” is in hunting season?"

Happy National Wear Red Day!



Cardiovascular diseases cause one in three women’s deaths each year. Go Red For Women is the American Heart Association's national movement to end heart disease and stroke in women, because 80 percent of cardiac events can be prevented with education and lifestyle changes.



What does it mean to GO RED?



Get your numbers: Ask your doctor to check your blood pressure, cholesterol and glucose.

Own Your Lifestyle: Stop smoking, lose weight, be physically active and eat healthy.

Raise Your Voice: Advocate for more women-related research and education.

Educate Your Family: Make healthy food choices for you & your family. Teach your kids the    importance of staying active.

Donate: Show your support with a donation of time or money.



Make a change at GoRedForWomen.org.

In February, we join together as one community to honor and recognize the importance of African-American history in America. We remember the struggles of African-Americans in the face of adversity and we celebrate the often neglected accomplishments by great men and women throughout our history. 



In Wisconsin, African-American history dates back to 1746 and the Wisconsin Black Historical Society has documented and preserved the historical heritage of people of African descent in Wisconsin through museum exhibits and other materials depicting our heritage.

 

This Black History Month, I encourage you to visit and donate to the Wisconsin Black Historical Society, a resource center for all people interested in Wisconsin's rich African-American heritage.

The legislation I authored intends to add four Dementia Care Specialists, and a Specialist focused on Dementia in the workplace.



I’m honored to play a part in our fight against these diseases that are affecting far too many of our loved ones,this bill is a targeted way to ensure that rural communities have the necessary resources to adequately care for those suffering from Alzheimer’s or Dementia.

“Wisconsin’s civil service laws are overdue for common-sense changes that keep pace with a changing workforce. The state’s hiring process will be more effective and top-quality employees can receive merit-pay bonuses. Employees will clearly know what actions are cause for immediate dismissal, and the appeals process will be streamlined. This bill builds off of the foundation established by Governor La Follette back in 1905 when he signed civil service protections into law in order to ensure that the best are serving our state.” 



“I am pleased that the final version of this bill contains a provision to “Ban the Box.” This means that the state will be prohibited from asking a job applicant to identify a conviction record as part of their application process, unless a conviction record disqualifies applicants from a civil service position. I believe that a job candidate should be judged on qualifications first, without the stigma of a conviction record, and the hiring process should be flexible enough to consider the circumstances involved and whether the former conviction relates to the job.”

Here is some important new information from the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development with regards to Disability Insurance:



Starting this week, the Division of Unemployment Insurance (UI), in order help more UI claimants transition back to employment quickly and meet employers' demand for talent, will revise its current system of waiving work-search requirements for claimants who expect recall from their employers. 



Highlights of the revisions include:



•	Claimants who expect recall by their employer may seek a waiver of the weekly work-search requirement for an 8-week period that can be extended for a maximum of 4 additional weeks with verification from the claimant's employer. Currently, waivers are approved through the end of a benefit year for a claimant who is not recalled.



•	The weeks of Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's will no longer be automatically waived for work search.



•	Claimants who will start work with a new employer within 4 weeks will  need to provide employer verification in order to obtain a work search waiver.  Employer verification is not currently required in these cases.



•	Claimants working part time for a customary employer (an employer for which the claimant works for more than 4 weeks or the claimant worked at least 32 hours during a given week) will have their work search waived, but will be required to register with Wisconsin Job Service through JobCenterofWisconsin.com and build a Job Match Profile.  This requirement is not currently in place for those with work search waivers.



These changes implement revisions to Chapter 126 and 127 of Wisconsin Administrative Code that the Legislature requested during the most recent legislative session.  DWD has now put in place the technology and operational framework to carry out these new requirements. 



As you are aware, UI claimants must be able to work, be available for work, and conduct a search for work when required. While the work search requirement may be waived when certain conditions are met under state law, such waivers are the exception, not the rule.  You also find more information about the work-search waiver online at

As a retired United States Air Force Officer, Dennis led countless troops overseas as well as at home defending our country and responsibly managing federal funds trusted to his care. 



Dennis has a Bachelor's Degree in Accounting from the University of San Diego and a Master's Degree in Organization Management from The George Washington University. 



Dennis has also tirelessly volunteered throughout the 67th District. The past several days in Louisiana and Minnesota have been very tough and my prayers go out to those who have lost a loved one. The loss of life in those incidents is hard to take, especially as someone who has worn the badge and taken an oath to protect and serve.  



As a former Texas Police Officer, just north of Dallas, I am heartbroken by the needless and senseless killings of the police officers who were doing their jobs and protecting the public. Any loss of life in this manner is a waste, and somehow, we as Americans need to come together and realize violence is never the answer. 



When an officer is killed in the line of duty, fellow officers wear a bland or mourning band over their badges to honor the fallen officer. Today I wear a band over my heart grieving for all the families involved and praying for those who were shot and injured, that they may recover. This is not the America I know

Democracy. It's the foundation of America. Wars are fought in its name. The concept is simple; people elect representatives and those representatives work for the people. 



Everyone seems to agree that the system is no longer working. Profiteers and their complicit politicians have rigged the game. Travis Tranel may have been one of us when he was first elected but he rapidly became a pawn of the profiteers. 



Tranel is a member of ALEC, The American Legislative Exchange Council. ALEC is literally corporations writing laws. Their complicit politicians then “author” and vote for the legislation. ...And guess who donates huge sums of money to their campaigns. Travis has introduced, co-sponsored, and voted for numerous ALEC bills. He is, quite simply, not working for us.



I believe in democracy. I will never quit fighting for “of the people, for the people, by the people." Help me fight these corrupt politicians and their "profits over people" agenda.



Together we can do better.

It's official, hunters: electronic registration of all deer and bear harvests will replace traditional registration in 2015.  As in the past, walk-in registration will still be available at many locations as well. The biggest change is that hunters will need to report their harvest online, by phone or in person no later than 5:00 PM the day after harvest.

The Vernon County Historical Society and Viroqua community members came together today for a groundbreaking ceremony for the new elevator that will be going into the Vernon County Museum. The Historical Society Board members spoke about the years of planning and fundraising that have gone into this effort, and they are excited to be able to make the museum more accessible for those who cannot walk the 47 stairs to the upper floors.



It is wonderful to see the community so invested in improving and maintaining this nearly 100 year old building that holds so much historical significance for the area.

Thank you to Senator Bernie Sanders for all that you have done for our party. Your vision of a progressive revolution has inspired millions of Americans to think big again. Your call to action has created a grassroots revolution-- the likes of which we have not seen in a generation. You are my inspiration and a brilliant example of who a true public servant should be.



You have put aside your own ego numerous times throughout your life for the good of the whole. Without your influence and willingness to work for a cause rather than yourself, you have begun the healing process after a long primary process. Your fight for a progressive platform and your resounding endorsement of Hillary Clinton proves your dedication to our cause and we will do well to remember that as we move forward.



While we have undoubtedly begun the progressive movement within the party, we recognize that there is still a long road ahead of us. This path may be long, but we have your example of four decades of public service to follow. Your examples of compromise and cooperation serve as important reminders as we begin our work with Secretary Clinton and her campaign to bring progressive politics back to the foreground of America.



From the bottom of my heart, I thank you for your unrelenting passion and dedication from your earliest days of service to your future endeavors. I pray that one day I will look back on my life and know that I was able to bring even one-tenth of the positive change to the world that you have.



So thank you for running, for being an example, and for inspiring me to dream big again.



-Noah Reif

Explanation of LRB 2824: Beginning in the 2017-18 school year, this bill requires school boards, operators of independent charter schools, and governing bodies of private schools to provide instruction in cardiopulmonary and cardiocerebral resuscitation in any health education course offered to pupils in grades 7 to 12 and to provide instruction about automated external defibrillators to pupils in grades 7 to 12.  Under current law, a school board, operator of an independent charter school, and governing body of a private school are required to offer instruction about cardiopulmonary and cardiocerebral resuscitation and to provide automated external defibrillators to pupils enrolled in high school grades.

I spent much of today at the Governor's Conference on Tourism at Ho Chunk Gaming where I was able to meet up with some constituents of the 41st District. It was great to see Jason Mansmith and Laura Kegler from the Ripon Chamber of Commerce, Liane Walsh and Roberta Martin from the Green Lake Chamber of Commerce, and Carrie Ivacko from Heidel House in Green Lake. 



Tourism Secretary Stephanie Klett shared some exciting news during her address. All counties saw an increase in tourism dollars spent in 2015. Statewide, we have 187,000 tourism employees. In 2015, we saw an eight to one return on tourism dollars invested by the state. The halo effect is real: visitors with a great experience are more likely to come to Wisconsin for college, career, vacation, or retirement. And most importantly, Sec. Klett told us that Wisconsin's tourism focus is all about telling people about the FUN you can have in Wisconsin.

FROM DOT:

Public meeting for Belknap Street in the city of Superior

Meeting to focus on preparations for the reconstruction of Belknap Street



The Wisconsin Department of Transportation (WisDOT) Northwest Region in Superior is announcing a public meeting to discuss the reconstruction of US 2, Belknap Street from Banks Avenue to Hill Avenue. WisDOT, in partnership with the City of Superior, will be holding the meeting on Thursday November 3, 2016.  There are two opportunities to attend this meeting; 7:30 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Both meetings will be held at Wisconsin Indianhead Technical College – Superior, Conference Center – Room C108, 600 N 21st Street, Superior, WI 54880.



This meeting will provide an update to the public on the project schedule, detours, access, local traffic through construction, and construction staging.  The improvement project on US 2, Belknap Street begins just west of the Banks Avenue intersection, continues east on Belknap Street, and ends west of the E. 7th Street intersection. Most of the connecting side streets would be reconstructed to the alleys, north and south of Belknap Street.   



Construction will begin in the spring of 2017, and is scheduled for two construction seasons, both 2017 and 2018.  The US 2, Belknap Street roadway will be reconstructed in separate construction zones and stages.  



WisDOT and City of Superior representatives will be available to discuss the construction project.  Superior Business Improvement District and The Chamber & Visitors Bureau - Superior-Douglas County Area staff plan to be present.  All interested residents and property owners are encouraged to attend the meeting, ask questions, and prepare for construction.  Citizens who are hearing-impaired and require an interpreter may request one by contacting the Wisconsin Telecommunication Relay System (TTY) at 1.800.947.3529. 



For additional information about the project, please visit the project website:

***FLAG HALF STAFF ORDER*** 

  

BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 

A PROCLAMATION

  

As a mark of respect for the memory of Nancy Reagan, I hereby order, by the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, that the flag of the United States shall be flown at half-staff at the White House and upon all public buildings and grounds, at all military posts and naval stations, and on all naval vessels of the Federal Government in the District of Columbia and throughout the United States and its Territories and possessions until sunset, on the day of interment.  I also direct that the flag shall be flown at half-staff for the same period at all United States embassies, legations, consular offices, and other facilities abroad, including all military facilities and naval vessels and stations. 

  

IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this seventh day of March, in the year of our Lord two thousand sixteen, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and fortieth.

  

BARACK OBAMA

I'm at the MLK Celebration in Stevens Point listening to Barbara Hickman powerfully articulate the power of a dream. She was the first black woman to graduate from the University of Wisconsin - Stevens Point and realized her lifelong dream of being a teacher. As she describes the hurdles of receiving inequitable pay and treatment, she underscores the importance of the work Martin Luther King Jr. dedicated his life to: his fight for human rights, civil rights, worker rights. "Who is keeping the dream alive?" she asks. 



Let's recommit ourselves to ensuring equal opportunity for all, a country where neighbors stand shoulder to shoulder with respect for each other's differences and shared interest in each other's successes. A country where we build each other up - a rising tide to lift all boats.

This has been a week of profound sadness and heartbreaking tragedy. We need to unite as Americans to promote peace and understanding and find solutions to these growing endemic problems. The words of the great civil rights leader seem most appropriate:

Let's keep fighting for every vote:

We just hit 1000 "likes" on this Facebook page!!! 



That's nearly as many "likes" in 5 months as the incumbent has received in the last 6 years. Individual posts have received over 9000 "likes" and over 1000 "shares." 



There is clearly something special about this campaign. It has us poised to win. It's not me. It's not some secret strategy. It is simply our message. 



We are all sick of politicians working for their donors rather than working for us. We all know that if we are to have a just and sustainable future- economically, socially, and environmentally, we need representatives that will fight for it rather than working to maximize campaign contributions. 



As far as the individual issues, I'm no fool. I know that very few of us will agree on every issue. I also know that, until we get rid of these bought-and-paid-for politicians, we have very little power to fundamentally address any of the individual issues. 



I will never quit fighting to end this current "legal bribery," anti-democratic, anti-American brand of governance. I will fight to restore government "Of the people, By the people, For the people." Nothing I do will be driven by political-expediency but rather by what I judge to be best for our district and our shared future. 



Keep Sharing! 



Together we can do better.

On Tuesday, Governor Walker announced a Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) major disaster declaration for northern Wisconsin counties impacted by flooding in July.  Applicant briefings with FEMA have been set up, which will provide an opportunity for local and tribal  officials and non-profit organizations to learn about the federal disaster aid program.  Officials and organizations will be able to submit applications for public assistance (infrastructure) at these briefings.  The Burnett County Briefing will be held on Tuesday, August 16th, from 2:30pm to 4:30pm at the Burnett County Government Center, Room 160 (7410 County Road K, Siren, WI).  For more information from the Division of Emergency Management at the Wisconsin Department of Military Affairs, see

FROM THE SUPERIOR TELEGRAM:

Douglas County considering outsourcing juvenile detention out of state



Posted on Mar 24, 2015 at 12:46 p.m.

Danielle Kaeding, Wisconsin Public Radio



A northern Wisconsin county is considering housing juvenile offenders in Minnesota because they are struggling to meet standards on where minors can be held.



Douglas County Administrator Andy Lisak said the Sheriff’s Department could contract with a juvenile detention center in Duluth.



“What we’re currently doing is transporting juveniles down to a detention center in Eau Claire,” Lisak said.



Jail Administrator Robert Galovich said that's because the county jail doesn’t meet regulations for housing young people.



“They don’t meet the criteria of being out of sight, out of the area. They need to be completely isolated,” Galovich said.



That's one of the requirements states must meet to receive federal incentive money, according to information provided by the Wisconsin Department of Justice. It's part of an effort to get facilities to comply with federal standards. The idea is that separating juveniles limits exposure to threats or abuse from adult offenders.



The state has 13 juvenile detention centers but none are farther north than Eau Claire or Marathon counties.



More WPR news is available on KUWS-FM 91.3 or online at www.wpr.org.

Governor Walker has issued an Executive Order that the U.S. and WI flag are flown at half-staff in honor of Trooper Trevor Casper.



The Governor released the following statement yesterday:



"Today, we recognize Trooper Trevor Casper for his heroism and remember his dedication to his community. Trooper Casper served the state faithfully and died protecting fellow citizens from harm. To honor his selflessness and sacrifice, the flags of the United States and the State of Wisconsin will be flown at half-staff. Tonette and I are keeping Trevor’s family and friends in our thoughts and prayers."



Flags will be flown at half-staff at all buildings, grounds and military installations beginning today and will remain lowered through Tuesday, March 31st.

Starting today, the Wisconsin Department of Transportation (WisDOT) is scheduled to close the entrance ramp from WIS 50 to US 12 westbound, in Walworth County. The closure is expected to last through the evening hours of Thursday, May 21. 

This closure will affect the morning commute on May 12 through the evening commute on May 21. 

This work is part of the US 12/WIS 50 project which began in spring of 2014. This closure was not originally anticipated to complete the work on this ramp. However, crews since discovered the condition of the pavement on the ramp has deteriorated beyond the point of economical repair. This will require more intensive work on the ramp which requires it to be shut down to traffic. 

Detour for WIS 50 westbound motorists: 

•	Proceed through the US 12/WIS 50 Interchange to access Edwards Blvd.

•	Go north on Edwards Blvd., continuing as it turns into Sheridan Springs Road.

•	Continue west on Sheridan Springs Road to County H (Interchange North Road). 

•	Go east on County H to access the US 12 westbound on-ramp at the WIS 120 Interchange.

The contractor will take advantage of the closure by performing other work items on the ramp that were to take place over several weeks of night time closures.  

 

WisDOT has scheduled this closure to occur prior to the Memorial Day weekend, in an attempt to limit disruption to traffic related to the summer tourist season.

VISION 2050 Open House

Tuesday, May 3 from 3pm - 5pm at YWCA (Milwaukee)

Please join the fifth VISION 2050 public input workshop and get a first look at the Southeastern Regional Planning Commission's regional transit and land-use draft plan. This is one of our final opportunities to weigh-in and share your vision for the future our region!



Since 2013, UEDA has partnered with SEWRPC to host public workshops, inviting the UEDA Community to provide their feedback on land use and transportation plans for Southeast Wisconsin. For a review of the past four sessions and to learn more about Vision 2050, visit vision2050sewis.org.

  

This workshop will use an interactive, open house format, so you are welcome to arrive at any time during the two-hour session. Attendees will:

•         Hear a brief overview on the information, data and feedback that was used in compiling the draft plan

•         Visit discussion stations that will provide you with the opportunity to learn about different aspects of the plan more in-depth

•         Share your opinion on the factors you believe should be considered when establishing the final plan



Your participation is important! Feedback gathered will help SEWRPC establish a comprehensive final plan.

Join on Tuesday, May 3 at 3:00pm!

This weekend I celebrated the ruling from U.S. District Judge James Peterson that found the Republican limitations imposed on early and weekend voting unconstitutional. Judge Peterson also overturned a law that extended Wisconsin's residency requirement from 10 days to 28, and another that created tough barriers to students using their school IDs to vote. These laws were nothing more than an effort to suppress the vote in certain districts and I applaud this decision to overturn them.



Unfortunately this ruling will not take effect in time for the August 9th primary. There is still time to vote absentee through August 5th. Find your polling place and what's on your ballot at myvote.wi.gov!

FROM DATCP:

EAB Found in Sawyer County; Quarantine in Process

Contact: Donna Gilson, 608-224-5130



MADISON – Emerald ash borer has been found in Sawyer County, the second most northern location in Wisconsin to date. The county will be quarantined.



"This new infestation is concerning, because it's getting to our North Woods, less than 20 miles from the Chequamegon National Forest and the adjoining Flambeau River State Forest. But it's not

surprising, given the ease with which this pest can hitchhike with the help of humans," said Brian Kuhn, director of the Bureau of Plant Industry in the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and

Consumer Protection. "Fortunately, the infestation appears to be in a very early stage, with no damage apparent yet, and even though it's in a heavily wooded area, very few of the trees are ash."



Only ash trees are susceptible to the destructive beetle.



A single adult beetle was found in a monitoring trap set by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service as part of its national survey for EAB. The trap was set along North Eastlund Road in the Town of Radisson.



The quarantine will apply to all of Sawyer County. It prohibits ash wood products and hardwood firewood from being moved out of the county to areas that are not infested. For private citizens, this

means that they cannot take firewood from Sawyer County to non-quarantine counties. For businesses handling wood products that could carry EAB, it means that they must work with DATCP or the USDA to assure that their products are pest-free before shipping.



DATCP recommends that property owners who have ash trees in quarantine counties:

-Keep a close watch on ash trees for signs of possible EAB infestation: Thinning in the canopy, D-shaped holes in the bark, new branches sprouting low on the trunk, cracked bark, and

woodpeckers pulling at the bark to get to insect larvae beneath it.

-Consider preventive treatments if your property is within 15 miles of a known infestation. Whether to treat depends on the age, size and number of ash trees. Treatment costs vary depending on size of the tree and whether you do the treatments yourself or hire a professional.

-Consider planting different species of trees that are not susceptible to EAB.

-Call a professional arborist for expert advice, and visit emeraldashborer.wi.gov for detailed information.



Emerald ash borer is native to China and probably entered the United States on packing material, showing up first in Michigan in 2002. It was first found in Wisconsin in 2008 in Washington County.

Sawyer County will join 38 other Wisconsin counties where EAB has been found: Adams, Brown, Buffalo, Calumet, Columbia, Crawford, Dane, Dodge, Door, Douglas, Fond du Lac, Grant, Green, Jackson, Jefferson, Juneau, Kenosha, La Crosse, Lafayette, Marquette, Milwaukee, Monroe, Oneida, Outagamie, Ozaukee, Portage, Racine, Richland, Rock, Sauk, Sheboygan, Trempealeau, Vernon,

Walworth, Washington, Waukesha, Winnebago and Wood. Iowa, Kewaunee and Manitowoc counties are also under quarantine because of the proximity of infestations in neighboring counties.

Another misleading column from Gov. Walker, this time about the state's vital yet increasingly neglected infrastructure. 



For example, he says that "97 percent of our most heavily traveled highways are rated in fair or above fair condition," which is his justification for underfunding transportation by billions of dollars over the next decade. According to my colleague Rep. Robb Kahl, the "most heavily traveled highways" Walker talks about make up only 1.4 percent of our road system. Overall, the U.S. Department of Transportation ranks Wisconsin as the state with the third-worst roads in the nation, with 71 percent of roads in poor or mediocre condition. 



We need to address our crumbling infrastructure immediately, not continue to kick the can down a road full of potholes.

Today, I spoke about Republicans' proposed repeal of the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) with 9to5 Wisconsin. FMLA helps hardworking Wisconsinites take time off if they become seriously ill, have a child, or need to care for a sick parent, spouse or child. No worker should have to choose between caring for their loved ones, or keeping their job. Currently, Wisconsin's FMLA is stronger than similar federal legislation. 

Let's keep it that way, and continue to stand up for our working families.

I grew up in a working class neighborhood on the South Side of Milwaukee.   I spent most of my free time at the Boy’s Club where I participated in competitive weight lifting and swimming, community service, archery and many more activities.  The Boy’s Club played a large part in shaping my character, and it taught me that non family caring adults can have a significant positive impact on the lives of youth.

I delivered the Milwaukee Journal   at the age of 12, and continued to work at part time jobs throughout my teenage years.  Since the age of twelve, I was responsible for buying my own clothes.

Due to living in a highly dysfunctional household, my high school academic career was poor. I did excel in both athletics and student leadership.  I was a three time city of Milwaukee wrestling champion and placed fifth in state my senior year. I was also both a high school and adult men’s state power lifting champion during my high school years.  I was my homeroom’s Student Council Representative all four years and held the office of Executive Committee Person in my junior year.

Upon graduating from Milwaukee Technical HS in 1974, I worked as a landscaper, dish washer, and insecticide sprayer in Florida. In 1976, I returned to Milwaukee where I worked for Instant Help, a temp job service, and I attended MATC through a CETA secretarial program.  After graduating, I enrolled at UW Richland Center where I studied and wrestled for two years.  I transferred to UW La Crosse and in 1983 earned a BS in K-12 Physical Education and Health Educational. After graduating, I worked for one year as a substitute teacher and homebound instructor for the school district of La Crosse.

From 1985-1988, I worked in La Paz, Bolivia at the American Corporative School as the Sport Facility Director and the Elementary Physical Education Instructor. 

From 1988-1990, I pursued my master’s degree in K-12 Counseling at UW-Superior.  After graduating, I worked for two years as a High School/Middle School Counselor at Nido de Aguilas International School in Santiago, Chile.  

In August of 1992, I was hired by the Nekoosa School District.  Throughout my tenure, I chaired numerous committees and played a major role in the establishment of Nekoosa’s Alternative School, High School Summer School Program, and Credit Recovery Program.   Due to my wife receiving a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimer’s, I took early retirement at the age of 55. My Chilean wife Rosario wanted to be near her son in Chile, so we move there in September of 2011, but we had to return in 9 months due to health insurance problems and the lack of supportive services.

Currently, with the help of Community Care Connect Wisconsin, I am the primary care giver for my wife who is now in the late stages of Alzheimer’s.  



I want to represent the 72nd in order to:

 

-help Wisconsin’s excellent public schools get even better, and find real solutions for impoverished students who struggle to learn.

-help existing Wisconsin businesses to prosper, while attracting new businesses to the state. 

-help find additional ways to exploit our world class university system in developing innovations that lead to more jobs for Wisconsinites. 

-bring creative ideas for improving state run social programs.

-develop policies that create a strong middle class.

-bring pragmatic independent problem solving skills to Madison.

I believe:

-having a strong middle class is a decision made by society.

-Public Schools are the bedrock of Democracy, and I believe that publicly funding private schools will be detrimental to our public schools, and will lead to greater division and strife among our citizens.

-all people can develop, and we need to invest in people.

-hope comes from a positive vision of the future.

-no one person is smarter than the collective effort of a diverse group.

Here is my official statement on the passing of Secretary Kitty Rhoades.



"On behalf of all of my fellow legislators, Democrats and Republicans alike, we send our deepest sympathies to the family of Secretary Kitty Rhoades.



"I am saddened to hear of her passing. Kitty was a great leader who helped shape the person I am today.  She was gracious, generous and incredibly talented at finding workable solutions to get things done.



"I had the privilege of learning under her leadership on the Joint Committee on Finance. Kitty helped me become a better legislator, taught me to focus on solving problems and find common ground when possible.



"My thoughts go out to her husband Frank, their sons and her entire family. 



"Kitty will be sorely missed and has left a lasting legacy in the legislature and the state of Wisconsin. She has influenced people and policy, and our state is a better state because of her."
