It was a pleasure to serve the constituents of the 99th Assembly District over the past four years, and I am enjoying the opportunity to continue serving them, as well as our neighbors in the 97th and 98th Assembly Districts, as your senator.



As Abraham Lincoln once said, "We have been the recipients of the choicest bounties of Heaven; we have been preserved these many years in peace and prosperity; we have grown in numbers, wealth and power as no other nation has ever grown." Let us all give thanks for our blessings and enjoy our fellowship this Thanksgiving Day.

Sen. Risser appointed to serve on Educational Communications Board

 

MADISON – Senator Fred Risser (D-Madison) has been appointed to serve on the Educational Communications Board (ECB) Board of Directors by Senate Democratic Leader Jennifer Shilling (D-La Crosse). The ECB is a state agency responsible for distributing K-12 educational media, public safety alerts and public broadcasting services to Wisconsin’s citizens. The ECB Board of Directors oversees efforts to improve telecommunication services across Wisconsin and leverage technology to enhance education opportunities. 



“Sen. Risser is an outspoken advocate for public broadcasting and brings a wealth of experience and leadership to the ECB Board,” said Sen. Shilling. “At a time when our schools and communities are facing difficult new challenges, Sen. Risser’s commitment to education opportunities and support for public infrastructure will be an asset to the ECB Board and its mission.”



"Wisconsin Public Broadcasting provides a vital service to its listeners and viewers," said Sen. Risser. "I am honored to be selected to serve on the Educational Communications Board and look forward to further expanding and improving its availability to all Wisconsin citizens."



Additional information about the ECB and the services it provides can be found online at www.ecb.org.

Tonight I attended the Spooner School Board meeting and would like to share some observations.



Hundreds of people showed up for this public hearing and the board only allotted 30 minutes for public testimony. I have never seen an elected body more unwilling to listen to the community that they are elected to represent. 



Allegations of widespread bullying have led the Spooner community to lose all faith in the school board. The recent mass exodus of teachers and staff wiped out 1000 years of institutional knowledge and experience. A huge number of kids have open-enrolled to get out of this district. Over 30 teachers in attendance stood up to acknowledge that they have felt bullied in the previous year. #SpoonerProud deserves better.

That is why I have introduced AB  221 which would save the state taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars and help cover tens of thousands of uninsured Wisconsinites. Many Republican states have sought waivers from the federal government to expand Medicaid through alternative, creative approaches. I have also introduced AB 101 to allow Wisconsin's Republican governor and legislature to model Medicaid expansion on those approaches from other states.

Just wish to pay my respects to the people who brought us Labor Day, paid for with blood, lives  and a lot of work from the American Labor Movement. Thank you. From our friend, Ralph Nader: "Labor Day should be used to reflect on the historic victories of American workers such as establishing the minimum wage and overtime pay, the five-day work week and banning of the use of child labor. Many in the U.S. would find it difficult to imagine living in a country where these things weren’t a given."



Labor Day is also a time to promote the future of labor and push our elected officials on the critical needs of workers, such as improved health and safety measures and increased economic benefits for tens of millions in need."

From History.com: 



Following approval of statehood by the territory’s citizens, Wisconsin enters the Union as the 30th state.



In 1634, French explorer Jean Nicolet landed at Green Bay, becoming the first European to visit the lake-heavy northern region that would later become Wisconsin. In 1763, at the conclusion of the French and Indian Wars, the region, a major center of the American fur trade, passed into British control. Two decades later, at the end of the American Revolution, the region came under U.S. rule and was governed as part of the Northwest Territory. However, British fur traders continued to dominate Wisconsin from across the Canadian border, and it was not until the end of the War of 1812 that the region fell firmly under American control.



In the first decades of the 19th century, settlers began arriving via the Erie Canal and the Great Lakes to exploit Wisconsin’s agricultural potential, and in 1832 the Black Hawk War ended Native American resistance to white settlement. In 1836, after several decades of governance as part of other territories, Wisconsin was made a separate entity, with Madison, located midway between Milwaukee and the western centers of population, marked as the territorial capital. By 1840, population in Wisconsin had risen above 130,000, but the people voted against statehood four times, fearing the higher taxes that would come with a stronger central government. Finally, in 1848, Wisconsin citizens, envious of the prosperity that federal programs brought to neighboring Midwestern states, voted to approve statehood. Wisconsin entered the Union the next May.

Three Walleye Limit Proposed for 2015 Season on Northern Lakes 



The Department of Natural Resources (DNR) has announced a proposal for a daily bag limit of three walleye for the season on most waters in northern Wisconsin.  The proposal, which affects only walleye, will be considered by the Natural Resources Board at its next meeting on April 8.  If it is approved by the DNR Board, it will still be subject to a public hearing and comment process.



The three walleye decision was reached to manage the population of sport fish in northern waters in the Ceded Territory and establish certainty for anglers.  DNR officials considered the number of fish that will be harvested by recreational anglers and by spearfishing in the Ceded Territory.  In recent years, tribal spearfishing has resulted in fewer fish harvested than predicted, which has caused DNR to adjust bag limits for other anglers at different points throughout the fishing season.  This has caused confusion and uncertainty.  The new three walleye daily limit for the 2015 season will be a consistent number that anglers can count on as they go out on the water. 



Detailed information about fishing guidelines on all lakes can be easily found through the DNR’s official Fish and Wildlife Guide mobile app, which is available for iPhone and Android.

My speech from the floor:



‘Twas the day before the big vote and all through our house,

The Ds talked so long it made the Rs grouse.

But as we have heard – this is your bill!

Though written by ALEC, you claim ownership still.



But why debate this bill, the budget is nigh,

What will this do to help unemployment so high?

Our budget, our budget, that’s what’s the matter

That’s the topic that’s arose such a clatter.



SeniorCare cut, leaving thousands off care, 

In hopes they would sign for Part D Medicare,

The UW was slashed, filling everyone with dread.

While visions of Minnesota danced in their heads.



My budget, my budget – anything else is a distraction,

Said Governor Walker, our state’s main attraction.

But during our distraction focused on this flap,

We realized suddenly we’d walked into a trap.



With provisions that harmed our dreams and our hopes,

It seemed like his budget was suddenly on the ropes.

When out of the blue there arose such a clatter,

Right to Work had arrived with such a big splatter.



Soon we all knew we had something to dread,

We had let bipartisan promises go right to our head.

They spoke barely a word, but went straight to their work,

Forcing us all into action, even the Chief Clerk.



No more talk of the budget that would hurt the middle class,

No more talk of a tax cut to give us some cash.

This brand new proposal, from just days ago

Gave rise to protests the cold weather couldn’t slow.



But where did this come from? Who sponsored this bill?

Where are our leaders to clean up this great spill?

Then off in Iowa our Governor did appear

Saying send me this bill, I’ll sign it right here!



But where did this come from, who sponsored this bill?

Who gets the credit for the unions it will kill?

Now the rules of our body say we can’t use our names.

Just like “No signs in the gallery” – it’s one of our games.



But how can we give credit where credit is due?

The best I can do is give you a clue.

WMC brought the bill, we know they’re the boss.

They cried, “On ALEC, on Walker, on Fitzgerald on --- he who must not be named!”



It started in the Senate with a hearing cut short,

Due to threats of danger or violence of some sort.

Once the gavel was banged, they were all through.

No one could talk, not even Cindy Loo Who.



Then it was straight to the floor – not a moment’s delay,

Where our Senators put in what they considered a long day.

They didn’t last long, not even past ten.

Our caucus has voted – we’re going longer than them.



On to the Assembly our hearing followed soon,

Where dozens of speakers filled up two whole rooms.

This time things went better, n’ere a one was thrown out.

(But we did have a few who decided to shout).



All kidding aside, we are actually quite grateful,

To have an exec, on that we’re so thankful.

To bring up amendments is something we do, 

But here on the floor, it’s something you eschew.



But party line votes left the amendments on the floor,

With all the work we put in, we had hoped for some more.

More cooperation, bipartisanship and common ground,

At the end of the day, I guess it couldn’t be found.



But back to the bill and the damage it will do.

I’ve heard from lots of people – I know you have too.

From small business owners, contractors and crews,

You call it workplace freedom, but they want freedom too.



If an employer wants a union, why should they be denied,

A label that says, “Made by a union with pride”?

Pitting one group against another is so very wrong

As Rodney King once said, “why can’t we all get along?”



Though the debate will continue, we know how it ends.

To the victor go the spoils is the message it sends.

But what about the rest of us, the beleaguered middle class?

If we ask for our fair share, you say kiss my ___



Ass-suming you’re serious about our taxpayers,

Then heed this advice from Uncle Steve the Soothsayer.

It’s not all that hard, it’s really not a riddle,

Just try to remember the folks in the middle.



Mr. Speaker, I say, we’ve heard it all before,

The middle class of Wisconsin can’t take it no more.

They’ve been working so hard to provide for their own,

But now it feels like we are trying to drive them from home.



So we sit in this chamber hour after hour

With all of our speeches getting no more than a glower.

We want to debate, we want to discuss,

We don’t want to stay up all night just making a fuss.



But the people back home keep writing us letters,

Asking us please, please make our state better.

They tell us their stories about their love of this state,

About conservation and education and other things great.



There are more important things that demand our attention,

And more without rhymes that I couldn’t even mention.

This bill is a distraction and a frustrating attempt,

To lure us away from a budget unkempt.



We should all be at home snuggled up in our beds, 

With thoughts of bipartisanship dancing in our heads.

But as it sits now, there’s no end in sight,

Unfortunately, Mr. Speaker, it’s going to be a long night.

Superior is a welcoming community that respects people of all faiths and ethnicities. This is the core of the fabric of our democracy, all people are created equal.

My Statement on the Passing of DHS Secretary Kitty Rhoades:



“Kitty will be greatly missed by all of us who had the pleasure of serving with her in Wisconsin state government.  I express my deepest condolences to her family, as well as her friends and her colleagues at the Department of Health Services.



“I am grateful for the opportunities I had to work with Kitty over the years.  I always respected her knowledge and admired her genuineness and depth of character. She was a dedicated public servant, and had a fierce commitment to advocating for the people she represented. She was a remarkable leader whose contributions to the state of Wisconsin will live on through the people and institutions grown and strengthened by her work.”

Ordinary people tell me that they want their kids to get a high-quality education, they want to protect our lakes, and they want their communities to be safe and for small businesses to thrive. Milroy Sworn-In for Fourth Term in State Assembly



MADISON- Representative Nick Milroy (D-South Range) was sworn in today for the 2015-2016 legislative session at the State Capitol in Madison. Conducting the inaugural ceremony was Chief Justice Shirley Abrahamson, the first woman to serve on the Wisconsin Supreme Court and its first female Chief Justice. Milroy has represented the 73rd Assembly District since 2009. 



“I am honored that the people of the 73rd Assembly District have again entrusted me to represent them in the State Assembly, and I look forward to working with my fellow legislators on both sides of the aisle to craft legislation that will move Wisconsin forward,” said Milroy. “As always, helping working families, protecting Wisconsin’s natural areas, and strengthening our state’s economy are among my top priorities. I will continue to do all I can to ensure that the voices of the people of Northwestern Wisconsin are heard in Madison.”

 

Rep. Milroy is assigned to four committees for the 2015-2016 legislative session. He will serve as Democratic ranking member of the Assembly Committee on Natural Resources and Sporting Heritage and the Committee on Mining and Rural Development, and he has seats on the Committee on Environment and Forestry and the Committee on Veterans and Military Affairs. Milroy will also continue to serve on the Sporting Heritage Council, the Legislative Council on State-Tribal Relations, and the Council on Military and State Relations.



Representative Milroy encourages the citizens of the 73rd Assembly District to contact him with questions or concerns regarding any state issue via email at Rep.Milroy@legis.wisconsin.gov or by calling (608)-266-0640 or (888)-534-0073 (toll free using Wisconsin-based phones).

From Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources:



"The snowy owl rescued by a DNR wildlife biologist Oct. 29 was released back into the wild today. It spent the past few weeks in rehabilitation at Bay Beach Wildlife Sanctuary.



“It was picture perfect,” said Lori Bankson , curator of animals at Bay Beach. “Today was fantastic. We were laughing because whenever we set up a release and talk about the wind ….well, it doesn’t always work out that way. This snowy went exactly the way we wanted him to go, to catch the wind and glide along the shoreline where the habitat is ideal.”



To assist DNR biologist Josh Martinez in the rescue, brewery managers at Titletown Brewery in Green Bayemployed a contractor to remove a permanent window that covered an old boiler hole high on the old, unused smokestack. The bird was weak and underweight but otherwise in good condition. By the time of its release, its weight had increased from 1,000 grams to 1,800 and it gained strength in a series of flight cages.



The release took place late this morning along the lakeshore near Bay Beach. Martinez and Brent Weycker, president of Titletown Brewing, had the honors of opening the transport cage and freeing the large, snowy white predator.



It is likely the owl, trapped in the smokestack shortly after a long migration from the arctic, will now seek to establish a feeding territory in Wisconsin for the remainder of the winter, Martinez said.



Thanks to Kristen Paquet for sharing her video."

Detours Ahead as St. Croix River Crossing Progresses



At the end of April, Wisconsin approach work on the St. Croix River Crossing will begin to impact traffic around Houlton.  Wisconsin approach work in 2015 will include grading from County Road E to WIS 64, constructing an interchange structure on County Road E, and constructing roundabouts at WIS 35 and County Road E.  



Beginning the week of April 27th, existing WIS 35/64 will have single-lane traffic in both directions at the north end of the project’s limits.  On May 4th, the southern access to Anderson Scout Camp Road from WIS 35/64 is anticipated to be closed until September 2015.  The detour for Anderson Scout Camp will be to take its northern access at the County V interchange. 



For more information on the project and road closings visit the link below.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to participate in a press conference on the devastating impact of the governor's budget and his continued refusal to accept federal Medicaid dollars. 



Wisconsin is a donor state, meaning we already pay more in taxes to Washington than we receive in services. Gov. Walker is turning away $345 million that Wisconsin taxpayers paid into the system. 



The governor’s rejection of this money is nothing more than a blatant attempt to bolster his conservative bona fides for his bid for the presidency. This means that the governor is willing to deny health coverage to 80,000 Wisconsinites in order to benefit one man – Governor Walker.

Just how many strikes does Planned Parenthood get?



Dr. Mary Gatter, President of Planned Parenthood Medical Directors Council was caught on tape discussing, “less crunchy” techniques of abortion and going through agreed upon rates of live children’s bodies so she can determine if she will make enough to get a Lamborghini.



If this makes you uncomfortable, it should, Planned Parenthood has been exposed as the worst female horror show imaginable.



More shocking, these illegal actions billed as women’s healthcare have been caught on tape over and over, with more to be released. Planned Parenthood’s private relationship between provider and expectant mother is not fostering women, its criminal.



Here are some of the illegal acts caught on tape at Planned Parenthood. 



1. Planned Parenthood has been caught coaching underage teenagers to lie about their age to receive an abortion.



2. Planned Parenthood has been caught telling women to wait until after five months to have their abortion if they want to abort a female fetus (five months is when the sex is usually determined).



3. Planned Parenthood has been advocating teenage girls as young as 14, to play various sex scenes from the movie, “50 Shades of Gray.”



Dr. Mary Gatter summarized Planned Parenthood’s callous mission as, “you know, the money is not the important thing for me, but it has to be enough that it makes it worthwhile for me.” In other words the only part of human life Planned Parenthood values is the part they can sell. In Wisconsin let’s not make it worthwhile. Planned Parenthood should be completely defunded of taxpayer money and their entire operations shut down, period. 



The list of state’s that have been fighting for the de-funding of Planned Parenthood now include; Ohio, Indiana, North Carolina, Kansas, Texas and New Jersey. 



Indiana was the first state that de-funded Planned Parenthood however a federal court ruled that a state cannot withhold funds to a medical provider based solely on that provider’s stance on abortion.  



That sounds reasonable when viewed through the lens of a society based upon law.  So what happens when a state denies funds to a medical provider because they break the law on a regular basis? 



In the 2015-2017 budget that recently passed in Wisconsin, I joined other likeminded legislators who were calling for a reduction in the Medicaid reimbursement rate for family planning prescriptions. The measure would have reimbursed at actual cost in lieu of the inflated rate that Planned Parenthood charges the taxpayers. The measure never made it out of the Joint Finance Committee (JFC) but would have saved the state about $5 million.  With the new atrocious videos that have emerged this week it’s time Wisconsin takes a real stand for women. No more strikes, it’s time to defund Planned Parenthood.



State Representative Janel Brandtjen

This proud daughter wishes a Happy Father's Day to a proud Navy veteran of WWII and the Korean War.  Here we are at the terrific Memorial Day program at the Sheboygan Veterans Memorial in 2015.  Six years ago, I got to join Dad on a Stars & Stripes Honor Flight to the WWII Memorial in DC, and it was one of the most memorable experiences of my life. All those Greatest Generation heroes in one place. He was among the youngest who served, because he signed up when he was only 17. Later he used the GI Bill to go to drafting school, and thus never joined the other Bulebosh men at the Humphries, PA coal mine that played such a big role in his childhood.

Kevin and Judy and their children are constituents of mine who I have gotten to know over the last two years.  This is a heartbreaking situation.  I sat with them and cried in their living room after hearing about Collin's condition.  I've introduced legislation to require newborn blood screenings to help detect Krabbe and similar diseases.  I've testified before a DHS committee on the same objective.  No family should have to watch as their child is slowly taken away from them by this or any other disease.

We can learn a lot from the Green Circle Trail. No one asks you if you're a Republican or a Democrat, what your profession is, or how much money you make. You greet everyone with a warm hello and smile because you're both enjoying the tranquility of the trail. You watch out for others and make sure everyone's got room. It's pristine because everyone respects their surroundings. 



We can learn a lot from the Green Circle Trail. Let's treat each other with the same warmth and kindness we do when we see each other in this beautiful place. Wishing you all the same peace and joy I find being out there.

My statement on the DOT Budget Proposal:



DOT Budget Proposal is a Solid Start



Wisconsin has two seasons - winter and road construction.  Yet, we have heard loud and clear from local government leaders from across the state that they need more money to fix and maintain roads and bridges.  For years, Wisconsin has prioritized large highway expansion projects over municipal maintenance and repair projects.  These misplaced priorities have left many of our town, county and other municipal roads in desperate need of attention.  



The budget proposal released today by the DOT goes a long way toward remedying this imbalance.  The DOT proposal includes a 5.5% increase in General Transportation Aid for local governments, a staggering 29% increase in bridge aid and a 25% increase in LRIP projects.  



Importantly, this proposal holds the line on taxes and contains reasonable and sustainable bonding levels (lowest since 2001-03).  I appreciate the hard work of DOT Secretary Gottlieb and the leadership shown by Governor Walker in proposing a transportation budget that is good for Wisconsin taxpayers.   I look forward to working with them next session on this important issue.

Here is a letter to the editor I jut submitted regarding the assaults on campus:



I have been a Whitewater resident for many years now.  I have served my community diligently in many roles and I love Whitewater very much.  But I must say that I am deeply concerned about the number of sexual assaults that have happened recently on this campus.  As a survivor myself, it worries me that day after day I receive e-mails from concerned parents and students about if they are safe on this campus and in this community.  When we hear ‘it takes a village to raise a child’ we must also apply this to other facets of life as well.  Working on and pushing forward the It’s On Us campaign here at UW-Whitewater for the last two years I know that there are dedicated individuals looking to solve this problem, however I’d like to point out that it will take the whole community to come together on this issue.  People come here to further their education and to grow as members of our society, not to worry about going outside alone to be assaulted.  I’d like to take this moment and ask that the University and the City of Whitewater come together to say that sexual assault is not okay and to look into options to solve this reoccurring problem.



-Allison M. Hetz

UW-Whitewater Student

43rd Assembly Candidate

Today, we remember the lives lost and a country forever changed by the atrocities committed on September 11, 2001.



The American people are resilient. This act of hate tested us, and we showed the world why America is great. In a time of unthinkable tragedy, we joined together and rose up as a nation. First responders and firefighters traveled from across the country to help search for survivors and clear debris in New York. Americans stood in line for hours to donate blood. Children broke open their piggy banks to contribute to efforts aimed at helping victims and their families. 



We clenched our fists in anger. We shed tears for those lost. We looked to the sky and asked why. But we didn't let this act of hate and terror destroy us. If anything, it made us stronger as a country.



May we forever remember those we lost on 9/11. May we also remember how we, as a country, came together to mourn, to rebuild, and to heal.

Today I circulated legislation to my colleagues which would allow Wisconsin residents suffering from a terminal illness to use investigational drugs that have not yet been approved for general use by the FDA, but have completed phase 1 clinical trials. This bill allows a terminal person hope for treatment where there may otherwise be none and rightfully gives patients and their doctors more control over medical decisions. Six other states have passed “Right to Try” laws in the past year, and 24 other states have introduced similar legislation.

***Consumer Privacy Bill Released***



Sen. Stroebel, Rep. Quinn and I released a bill yesterday that we had been working on with Abate of Wisconsin Inc. for several months now.



In an age of constantly evolving technologies including smart phones, Google Earth cameras and drones, it is a challenge to ensure that personal privacy is protected.



This legislation will codify who can have access to the data that is recorded on a vehicle's EDR (Electronic Data Recorder).  In short, it cannot be released unless the vehicle's owner provides written consent - with certain exceptions to include court orders and auto mechanics in an effort to diagnose a problem.



Insurance companies will no longer be allowed to modify, decline or cancel a policy if they are not allowed access to EDR data.  This does not limit an insurance company from contracting with a vehicle owner through a usage-based policy that would allow the insured to lower their rates based on driving habits.



My press release can be located at:

The Government Accountability Board (GAB), age 8, died on November 7, 2015, after a long battle with Republican lawmakers and special interest lobbyists. The Government Accountability Board was born February 2, 2007 to a proud group of legislators focused on a fair and ethical elections process. Wisconsinites were deserving of the impartial, nonpartisan oversight of their elections and will mourn the loss of the GAB.



The GAB in was created upon the death of the Wisconsin Elections and Ethics Boards, ineffective partisan boards, desperately in need of reform. The Government Accountability Board is now survived by the Elections and Ethics Commissions, a new similarly ineffective, gridlocked, partisan board, reminiscent of the GAB’s predecessor. 



The Government Accountability Board reached national notoriety and accomplished a great deal in its lifetime. The GAB was at the helm of unprecedented recalls and navigated elections in a smooth and effective manner during the constantly changing laws governing it. It will be dearly missed by many. 



In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Wisconsin Club for Growth.

There are days when I know it's too much to bear for a lot of hard-working people who don't deserve to have the burdens. People across Wisconsin lose sleep at night as they worry about paying for childcare, putting their kids through college, making their student loan payments, and planning for their retirement. Workers are tired of hearing they have to go another year without a raise - and by the way they have to do with fewer rights, too. The continued attacks on every worker who makes our state great have made morale plummet. I understand and I share your frustrations.



Sometimes it helps to put it all in perspective. To study the past, and think long into the future about where we could be and how we could get there: through a renewed commitment to our state, our community, and each other.



Pope Francis' words today were a call to action: to embody the spirit of service and live to serve. Every one of us can find a way to serve our community and lift each other up in unique and inspiring ways. So though many of us may feel we are fighting for Wisconsin's soul, we should look to each other and remember that we're all we have. Long after we're gone, the one thing that will remain is the community we built. It's up to us to make the best one possible.

To all of my aviation related friends... and possibly drone friends out there, I am putting together some of the first legislation regarding drones and aviation safety at a state level.  The FAA is taking far too long to address the issue.



I am afraid that eventually, as with many aviation regulations, this will be addressed by writing it into the FAR's in blood.



If you have any comments or would like to weigh in on the issue, please do.  I want to hear from commercial drone operators, Army aviation safety officers, medical helicopter operators, recreational drone operators, charter aircraft owners, and airport managers.  I did have a good discussion with a couple of Madison air traffic controllers and an FAA drone expert this morning.



Please contact me at rep.kremer@legis.wi.gov and provide "Drones" in the subject of the email.  Provide your phone number so that I can follow up if need be also.



Thank you!



PS Feel free to tweet #widrones

Last week I had the pleasure of attending a field trip with the Auburndale FFA program. For Farm Safety Day, the FFA visited Liquid Coin Dairy in Milladore, WI. The 4th and 5th grade students learned about agriculture and how stay safe on a farm. One thing that struck me about Liquid Coin Dairy was the tremendous technological advances they are able to use on their farm. The technology is apparent in everything including milking cows, feeding calves, and the GPS technology used in planting. 



Today I got a very nice thank you note from the students and I wanted to say THANK YOU to those students and to Liquid Coin Dairy for a memorable day.

Tribute to a fallen hero

 

This weekend, our community lost a hero. Gary Green’s fight with lung cancer came to an end. Gary wasn’t a smoker. He was a firefighter, “Firefighter Gary,” who served for 25 years as a captain, EMT, Haz-Mat team coordinator, rescue team member, and a fire investigator. There is a sad fact that you probably didn’t know – firefighters die from lung cancer at much higher rates than the rest of the population.  Firefighters literally give their lives to save ours in ways we never realize.

 

Gary’s generous spirit and passion for helping others carried over from his personal life, where he was a devoted husband, father and grandfather, to his professional life. He gave his body and his life in the service of the people of our state.  Gary died as a result of his selfless service in keeping his community safe for a quarter century.

 

I was hoping to meet with Gary shortly before he died, but wasn’t able to get back home from vacation in time.  He wanted to talk with me about how we treat our firefighters, police officers and other public servants.  Gary always gave more than he asked in return.  But it saddened him when people ignored the true sacrifice these heroes make every day and instead focus on how much they are paid or what their employment benefits are.  But how can you put a price tag on a commitment that causes you to rush into burning buildings, that literally makes you walk through fire to save your fellow man?  

 

One of the things I am most proud of in our country is our continuing dedication to active duty military and our veterans. They have put their lives on the line for our country time and time again and they have earned our support and respect a hundred times over. And so have people like Gary. Our firefighters and police officers have dedicated their lives to putting the safety and protection of our community ahead of their own. These heroes deserve that same respect.

 

Thank you for your service, Firefighter Gary. Heroes like you will never be forgotten.  Godspeed.

We must put a stop to the current corrupt campaign finance system in Wisconsin that amounts to legalized bribery.



Campaign finance reform is the single most important issue of our time because it affects all other issues. When multimillionaires like our opponent can buy elections, the rich get richer and the working and middle class get poorer. 



We must return to a public financing election system that was in place for 33 years before 2011 in the state of Wisconsin so you don’t have to be super wealthy to run for public office to serve the residents in this state. The middle class should be represented in Wisconsin by middle class representatives, not millionaires and billionaires.



We must overturn the disastrous Supreme Court decision known as “Citizen’s United” that allows corporations to spend unlimited amounts of money on elections. When corporations can buy elections it’s not democracy, it’s oligarchy. We can overturn this by having two thirds of the states call for an Article V Convention to propose a Constitutional Amendment.

You Can Make a Difference

by Rep. Jesse Kremer



Contrary to popular belief, the United States was organized as a republic, not a democracy. In a republic, the people elect individuals to represent their interests at the local, state or federal levels of government. In order to truly represent the 59th Assembly District, it is imperative for me to have a pulse on your concerns and interests.



If you have ever sat in on any of my presentations, you are keenly aware of my passionate belief that the best ideas do not come from legislators or governors, but from the well-informed electorate.



During my campaign for office last summer, I made it very clear to residents of the district what my personal, religious and ideological views were. Sometimes, however, my personal views may not align perfectly with the majority.



When taking difficult votes, I remind myself that I represent the district as a whole. While I do not always have the best answers to reforming government, running our state more efficiently or curing our social ills; many of you do. So far this year, I have already introduced several pieces of legislation as a direct result of constituent input.



If you have not done so already, I encourage you to become involved in your government and engage in this process by providing your input.



One way you can do this is to attend listening sessions held by your state and congressional elected officials. This coming Saturday, Nov. 21, I will be hosting a day of listening sessions, with stops in Hartford, Kewaskum, Campbellsport, Mt. Calvary and New Holstein.



More details on times and locations can be found at my website, repkremer.com. I hope you will take advantage of this opportunity to come share your thoughts, or just listen and learn. I look forward to hearing from you this weekend.

I’m proud to be endorsed by the Sierra Club.



As a kid in Bagley, we were either in the Mississippi River or exploring the diverse natural communities and monumental scenery of the riverbluffs. We drank from springs, ate wild foods, built fires, and smelled the earth. Our families and neighbors were farmers, loggers, hunters, trappers, and fisherman. It was impossible to not see the environment as our one and only life support system.



The natural world is the basis for everything: us, our food, water, air; our economy; our future. I've spent my entire adult life working to protect and maintain it: as a farmer, as a volunteer, and with the business I founded. As a politician, I will never stop fighting for a sustainable environment and a sustainable future.



Together we can do better.

After thoughtful consideration, I am announcing my candidacy to represent our 49th District in our Wisconsin State Assembly. 



I am a Progressive. For my entire adult life, I have believed that we can do better. For all our amazing accomplishments, our society faces extremely serious challenges. As individuals and collectively, we must do better when things are going poorly.  Similarly, there is no reason why we cannot do better even when things are going well- build on our successes and failures.



We are better together. Rugged individualism and self-responsibility are incredibly honorable attributes. It is, however, cooperation- working together, building upon one another's strengths, and mitigating one another's weaknesses that has fostered our species' greatest achievements. Government is simply a technology; together we can take responsibility and make it work for us.



We are all in this together. We have one planet, one life-supporting ecosystem; without it we have no future.  Greed, inequality, racism, sexism, fear, hate, and suffering foster a vicious cycle of greed, inequality, racism, sexism, fear, hate, and suffering. We are better together. 



The status quo is not sustainable. Consumerism, narcissism, depression and hopelessness, violence, poverty and suffering, ecological collapse- we face big problems. The economic and political systems have been rigged to work for the few that have rigged it. We have largely given up on government.  



I am a Progressive. Together we can do better.



Jesse Bennett

Your progressive candidate for the 49th District's Representative to the Wisconsin State Assembly

13761 County Road CX

Bagley, WI 53801



My biography:

I was born & raised in Bagley, WI and have been a lifelong resident of Wisconsin's 49th District. After high school I studied Philosophy and Sociology at UW-P. I've been married for over twenty years to wife, Jaye Maxfield. We are both proud to have been raised by hard-working families of very modest means. Together, Jaye and I started with nothing and built a successful business, now in its nineteenth year. Our farm and business is 100% solar and firewood powered and we produce much of our own food.



I started my career working as a Merchant Marine traveling the Mississippi, Ohio, Illinois, and Tennessee River systems. Beginning as a deckhand, I worked my way up to become the youngest-ever Chief Engineer for American Commercial Barge Line. Before leaving to start my own business, I had been promoted to middle management overseeing major shipyard repairs, engine overhauls, compliance with new US Coast Guard regulations, and vessel maintenance emergencies.



In 1997 I founded Driftless Land Stewardship LLC- one of the region's first companies specializing in natural areas management, invasive species control, large-scale prescribed fire, and ecological restoration. We average 6-8 full time permanent employees and are a proud contributor to the local economy. As a socially-responsible employer, our employees are paid more than the co-owners and our company donates services of approx. $10k annually to local conservation projects.



In 2006 I founded Hazelton Brush Goats which has grown to become the largest commercial meat goat operation in Wisconsin. Our goats are also used by Driftless Land Stewardship for weed and brush management. We are proud to be the first and largest prescribed grazing provider in the Midwest.



I have been actively involved in the non-profit conservation community for decades. I am former president and current board member of the Southwest Chapter of the Prairie Enthusiasts, a local conservation organization. I have been instrumental in establishing local nature preserves including Borah Creek Prairie State Natural Area near Fennimore, WI. In 2010 I was recognized as “Prairie Enthusiast of the Year” by The Prairie Enthusiasts. I am a frequent lecturer on a number of ecology and wildlife-related subjects.



I am a Progressive. Together we can do better.

#TBT My grandmother Sophie was a great role model growing up.  I didn't realize many of the struggles she faced during her lifetime because she did not share them with us until she was gone. 



While I was growing up I didn't  know that she was married prior to my grandpa. 



Her first husband was killed  during WWII over north Africa in a Bomber.  They were only married for 11 months and she was notified by telegram the day after their one year anniversary.  I found the purple heart with the scrapbook that tells their love story and wanted to share Joseph Wojcik's story to honor those that gave the ultimate sacrifice to our country and protect freedom throughout the world.  We should never forget.

PROPANE UPDATE:



FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 

January 9, 2015

Contact: Laurel Patrick, (608) 267-7303

 

Governor Scott Walker Declares Energy Emergency as Precaution Measure for Propane Customers During Cold Weather

 

Madison – Governor Scott Walker has declared a State of Emergency as a precautionary step in response to unexpected and intermittent service interruptions on the Mid-America East Blue Pipeline at the Janesville terminal.  January and February are months that propane customers typically begin refill their tanks, and with the cold weather temperatures forecasted this week and next, this precautionary declaration allows propane truck drivers to travel to other terminals if they need to, to bring supply into the state.

 

“We’ve taken a number of steps in the past year to help avoid another propane shortage like the one that impacted the Midwest last winter, and it’s important that we continue to take proactive measures to avert issues whenever possible,” Governor Walker said.  “Early indications suggest that this is a short-lived supply interruption, but given the forecast, we are exercising caution to protect the health and safety of our citizens which is first and foremost.”

 

The Mid-America East Blue Pipeline is below capacity and has recently experienced intermittent service interruptions.  This pipeline serves four states, including the Janesville, Wisconsin; Dubuque, Iowa, and Rockford, Illinois, terminals and storage facilities.  The Janesville and Dubuque terminals are crucial in supplying propane to southern Wisconsin, but they are also used to help supply propane to other areas of the state.

 

On January 8, 2015, deliveries resumed to most Mid-America East Blue Pipeline propane terminals, but operations at the Janesville terminal, the last stop on the line, still remain intermittent.  

 

As always, carriers remain responsible for ensuring they operate safely during the Energy Emergency and if we can safely end the declaration earlier, because operations have resumed at full-capacity, we will look to do that.

 

The Department of Administration’s State Energy Office will closely monitor the supply for the 250,000 customers who use propane in Wisconsin.

 

Governor Walker serves as Chair of the Midwestern Governors Association, and the propane supply to the Midwest has been the Governor’s primary initiative.  Below are just several of the preventative measures taken in 2014 to help ensure an adequate propane supply in Wisconsin:  

 

• February 2014 – Governor Walker requested that the federal government establish a propane supply chain working group.  On February 1, 2014, Governor Scott Walker sent a letter to President Barack Obama urging his administration to establish and lead a propane supply chain working group to coordinate the movement of propane from where it is available to where it is needed in the United States. 

 

• Summer 2014 – Summer Fill Program.  The Department of Administration’s State Energy Office reports that about 50 percent more propane came into Wisconsin in the months of June, July, and August 2014.  This indicated that consumers responded to summer-fill programs, and many propane marketers around the state reported that more customers purchased propane during the summer than ever in the past. 

 

• August 2014 – WHEAP Early Fill Program.  State energy officials reached out to 25,000 households across Wisconsin that participate in the Wisconsin Home Energy Assistance Program (WHEAP) to help fill their propane tanks before the cold weather set in.   DOA’s WHEAP program began processing applications in August (instead of starting on October 1 when the program officially begins) for the 11 percent of WHEAP households that use propane.  WHEAP estimated the amount of heating benefit a customer would receive and then locked in the lower summer price with a propane dealer who worked directly with the WHEAP customer to establish a future delivery date.   More consumers took advantage of the early application process in the WHEAP program than ever before.

 

• October 2014 – new Hixton propane terminal opened.  Built by CHS, this new terminal has the ability to store 360,000 gallons of propane, offload six railcars every four and a half hours, and load six trucks per hour in the terminal’s two truck loading bays.  The terminal also features modern terminal automation and safety technologies. CHS signed a long-term agreement with Federation Cooperative in Black River Falls to build the terminal at 144 Depot Street South in Hixton.  Federation Cooperative will manage and operate the propane terminal.



In 2014, the Cochin pipeline, owned by Kinder Morgan, Inc., was repurposed to become an export pipeline to ship natural gas condensates to Canada, resulting in a loss of propane supply into the Upper Midwest of about 300 million gallons annually.  The Hixton terminal is a part of a $24 million CHS investment in four states, and is expected to bring approximately 15 million gallons of new supply into Wisconsin annually to help offset the loss of supply that would otherwise have come from the Cochin pipeline.

May 26, 2015                 

715-839-9500



Rep. Dana Wachs Endorses Hillary Clinton for President



EAU CLAIRE-On Tuesday, June 2, 2015, Representative Dana Wachs (D-Eau Claire) announced his endorsement of Hillary Clinton for President of the United States.



“Like so many people throughout Wisconsin and the rest of the country, I was extremely excited to hear that Hillary Clinton is running for President,” said Wachs.  “She has the intelligence, the experience, and the common sense that is needed to lead our country. Hillary Clinton has dedicated her life to public service, and that sense of duty to her country is what will make her a strong leader and a great President. I am proud to offer my complete endorsement of her candidacy for President of the United States.”



Rep. Wachs was elected to the Assembly in 2012, and represents the 91st Assembly District, which is made up entirely of the City of Eau Claire.



Prior to his election to the Assembly, he served on the Eau Claire City Council.  Rep. Wachs is a lifelong resident of Eau Claire.  A graduate of Memorial High School, he is married with 3 children who also attended Memorial High School.  In addition to serving in the Assembly, he is a practicing attorney with 30 years of experience. He practices at the firm of Richie, Wickstrom and Wachs LLP.



“In my years being involved in politics both as an engaged activist and an elected office, I have rarely seen anyone with the skill set that Hillary Clinton will bring to the White House,” added Wachs.  “In addition to her experience building and fostering international relationships that are absolutely vital in today’s global environment, she has dedicated her career to serving her fellow Americans and giving everyone an opportunity to reach the American Dream. I look forward to a spirited campaign and I will work hard to ensure that Hillary Clinton is the next President of the United States.”

"Good luck, Nanette. I hope you win!"  



I've heard and read this many times, especially in the last few days. I hope I win this election too. I'll be the first Democrat to hold this seat in more than 30 years. And the first woman ever. 



The fact is, though, on a personal level, I've ALREADY won. 



I've shaken hands with inspiring people, young and old. I've listened to memorable stories. I've made a whole slew of new friends. I've reconnected with old ones (a very sweet thing). And I've been on the receiving end of more gestures, more creative help (best campaign team ever!), more warm words, and more kindness than any one person has a right to.



I regret not being organized enough to keep a journal, but I will have one hell of a photo album.  Here's a little part of it.  I hope it inspires some of you to run for office yourself.  



I highly recommend it.

Rep. Kremer and Sen. LeMahieu circulated a bill that will allow small businesses (grossing under 5 million adjusted annual sales) some predictability regarding Dept. of Revenue audits:



1. The interest rate will drop from 12% to a market rate of federal reserve prime +1 over the period of several years.  Beginning on January 1, the interest rate will be reduced by 0.5% a year until the market rate is achieved.



2. Audit timeline will be 240 days max.



3. First time audit will be a "learning experience" and no interest paid (unless negligence/fraud).



4. Interest will not compound during the audit period.

Rivers2Lake Education Program receives grant, expands program



SUPERIOR, Wis. – Rivers2Lake, the dynamic mentoring program that helps teachers integrate Lake Superior into classrooms, has received a new $75,000 grant from NOAA’s Great Lakes Bay Watershed Education Training Program (B-WET), with funds provided by the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. The funds allow the program led by the Lake Superior National Estuarine Research Reserve to expand along Wisconsin’s South Shore during the 2016-17 school year, in partnership with the Bad River Watershed Association. The Lake Superior National Estuarine Research Reserve is led by the University of Wisconsin-Extension, in partnership with the University of Wisconsin-Superior. 



Seventeen teachers from schools in Superior, Ashland, Bayfield, Floodwood, the Fond du Lac Reservation of Lake Superior Chippewa, Carlton and Duluth joined the program this year. The teachers participated in a Summer Institute from August 2 to 5, where they explored the watershed with scientists, resource management agencies and tribal experts, and practiced place-based and outdoor learning techniques. During the school year, Deanna Erickson, education coordinator at the Lake Superior National Estuarine Research Reserve, Ryan Feldbrugge, education mentor at the Reserve, and Dr. Toben LaFrancois at the Bad River Watershed Association will collaborate with the teachers in Rivers2Lake classrooms bi-monthly.



Rivers2Lake integrates the Lake Superior watershed into education as a foundation for engaging place-based learning, Great Lakes literacy, stewardship and watershed restoration The NOAA grant allows the program to provide funding for bus transportation, on-water learning experiences in boats or canoes and funding for classroom resources, with an intent of eliminating barriers to outdoor education in schools. The program also helps to network teachers with biologists, research managers, environmental educators and historians in an effort to bring real-world Great Lakes learning to students. Rivers2Lake collaborates with the Great Lakes Aquarium, Fond du Lac Resource Management, Northland College and the Northern Great Lakes Visitor Center, among others.



The Lake Superior National Estuarine Research Reserve, a research program based at UW-Superior and jointly operated by UW-Extension and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is a federal reserve encompassing over 16,000 acres along the St. Louis River freshwater estuary.

Wisconsin's onerous Voter ID law is once again halted for the November Election.



A federal judge on Tuesday ruled that Wisconsin residents without photo identification can vote in Wisconsin's November election if they sign an affidavit swearing to their identity.



Federal Judge Lynn S. Adelman said a “safety net is needed for those voters who cannot obtain qualifying ID with reasonable effort.” He went on to say that signing an affidavit is “a sensible approach that will both prevent the disenfranchisement of some voters” and “preserve Wisconsin’s interests in protecting the integrity of its elections.”



Thankfully this law, inspired by Madison Republicans and which has been costly to Wisconsin taxpayers, has been halted while the lawsuit is still pending. Since voter fraud in Wisconsin is essentially nonexistent and is many times more rare than being killed by a bolt of lighting, it always was a "solution desperately in search of a problem". On the other hand 9% of registered voters in Wisconsin lacked a government-issued ID when the law was first passed.



It has long been suspected that the sole purpose of this law was to disenfranchise Democratic voters like college students and minorities. In fact it has been fairly clear that this law has disproportionately affected college students and minorities. Our SD10 district has two UW system schools and two technical colleges, and many of these students have and would continue to have their right to vote be adversely affected by this law.



Stay tuned as more information will be forthcoming on how this ruling will be implemented at the ballot box in November.

Friday, Oct. 2 is National Wrongful Conviction Day. Tomorrow, Rep. Dale Kooyenga (R-Brookfield), Sen. Van Wanggaard (R-Racine), Sen. Fred Risser (D-Madison), and I will announce a new bipartisan plan to overhaul Wisconsin's exoneree compensation law.



Wisconsin's wrongful conviction compensation, currently capped at a lifetime total of $25,000, is the worst statutory compensation plan in the nation. It's time to change that.



We'll hold a press conference tomorrow at 10:15 a.m. in the Assembly parlor to outline our plan. Stay tuned.

I recently had the opportunity to stop by and meet with students at the Green Bay Boys and Girls Club to discuss the Be Great, Graduate program. I worked with several of my colleagues in the Assembly to pass a budget motion that will increase funding to the program to $150,000 over the biennium. This is a great program that focuses on mentoring at-risk students to ensure they are receiving the resources they need in order to graduate. I am very proud of the work the Club has done in our community and am honored to have played a part in supporting this program!
